    "let @xmath7 be a subvariety of a torus @xmath8 over an algebraically closed field @xmath9 endowed with a non - trivial valuation @xmath10 . denote by @xmath11 the ideal of @xmath7 in the ring @xmath12 $ ] of laurent polynomials . denote by @xmath13 the images in the ring @xmath14 $ ] of the canonical coordinate functions @xmath15 on @xmath8 .",
    "if @xmath16 is the real vector space generated by the lattice @xmath17 of @xmath18-parameter subgroups of the torus @xmath8 , we may also think about a vector @xmath19 as a weight of the variables @xmath15 . then",
    ", by definition , the @xmath20-initial ideal @xmath21 is generated by all @xmath20-initial forms of elements of @xmath11 ( see also section  [ s : powerseriesring ] ) .",
    "one associates canonically to @xmath22 a polyhedral set ( that is , a set that may be represented as a finite union of convex polyhedra ) in @xmath16 .",
    "this set is called _ the tropicalization _ of @xmath23 .",
    "it can be defined in at least three different but equivalent ways , expressed as conditions ( 1 ) , ( 2 ) and ( 3 ) in the following theorem ( see @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) :    [ t:3defs ] the following subsets of @xmath16 coincide ( the horizontal bar meaning the closure with respect to the usual topology of @xmath16 ) :    1 .",
    "[ pointsvp ] @xmath24 .",
    "[ invp ] @xmath25 .",
    "[ valvp ] @xmath26 \\mbox { extending } v\\ } } $ ] .",
    "our initial aim was to define _ a local analog of tropicalization _",
    ", adapted to the study of singularities and of their deformations .",
    "more precisely , we wanted to tropicalize ideals of formal power series rings of the form @xmath27 $ ] , where @xmath9 is any field , and to compare them with the previous ( global ) tropicalizations .",
    "as subvarieties of tori are most naturally studied by taking their closures in associated toric varieties , we wanted to be able to define , more generally , tropicalizations of ideals in formal completions of the coordinate rings of affine toric varieties at their closed orbits , that is , in rings of the form @xmath28 $ ] , where @xmath1 is a ( not necessarily saturated ) finitely generated subsemigroup of a lattice . in the sequel , following @xcite , we call such semigroups _ affine_. in order to get more geometric flexibility ( see remark [ reasnn ] ) , we consider not necessarily normal toric varieties , that is , not necessarily saturated semigroups .    in order to compare local and global tropicalizations , we have to change the ring defining the object under study .",
    "that is why we need to develop a sufficiently general functorial framework for tropicalization . among the characterizations 13 in the previous definition of ( global )",
    "tropicalization , it is the third one which lends itself most easily to such a functorial treatment .",
    "this is not surprising since the set described by ( [ valvp ] ) is an image of berkovich s analytification of @xmath7 , see @xcite .",
    "therefore , we propose the following general framework for tropicalization ( both local and global ) :    * start from a semigroup morphism @xmath29 from an affine semigroup to the multiplicative semigroup of an arbitrary commutative ring . *",
    "consider the space @xmath3 of valuations of the ring @xmath0 with values in @xmath30 .",
    "* consider the tautological map : @xmath31 * if @xmath6 is any subset of @xmath3 , its _ tropicalization _ is defined as the image @xmath32 .",
    "this construction is a functor from the category of pairs @xmath33 and commutative diagrams of morphisms between such pairs to that of maps @xmath34 and commutative diagrams between them .",
    "we speak about _ local tropicalization _",
    "when @xmath35 is a local ring , @xmath5 is a local morphism ( that is , @xmath36 is the set of non - invertible elements of @xmath1 ) , and @xmath6 is a subset of the space of valuations centered on @xmath0 ( that is , nonnegative on @xmath0 ) .",
    "there are two main instances of local tropicalization .",
    "the _ positive tropicalization _ of @xmath0 with respect to a local morphism @xmath5 is the tropicalization of the space @xmath6 of valuations which are strictly positive on the maximal ideal @xmath37 of @xmath0 .",
    "the _ nonnegative tropicalization _ is defined similarly , with the only difference that we tropicalize all nonnegative valuations on @xmath37 .",
    "we consider the following particular instances of the previous definition :    * @xmath38 , @xmath39 $ ] where @xmath7 is an algebraic subvariety of the torus @xmath8 , @xmath5 is the natural morphism which sends each basis vector @xmath40 of @xmath17 to the image @xmath41 in @xmath14 $ ] of the corresponding variable @xmath42 , and @xmath6 is the set of valuations extending the given one on @xmath9 .",
    "therefore , as a special case of our definition , we get the third version of the definition of the tropicalization of a subvariety of a torus as in theorem  [ t:3defs ] .",
    "* @xmath1 is an arbitrary saturated affine semigroup , @xmath39 $ ] , @xmath7 being an algebraic subvariety of the affine toric variety @xmath43 $ ] defined by @xmath1 over @xmath9 and @xmath6 is the whole space @xmath3 .",
    "we get then the notion of tropicalization of a subvariety of a normal affine toric variety introduced by payne @xcite .",
    "our definition of local tropicalization can be applied in the following new setting :    * we let @xmath44 be an ideal of a power - series ring @xmath28 $ ] , @xmath45 / i$ ] , @xmath5 be the natural semigroup morphism associating to each element of @xmath1 the image in @xmath0 of the corresponding monomial , and @xmath6 be the subspace of @xmath3 of valuations centered at @xmath0 which extend the trivial valuation of @xmath9 .    our main structural results about tropicalization state the piecewise - linear structure of the local positive tropicalization ( see theorem  [ t : main ] and proposition  [ globloc ] for the general statements ) . to give the reader an idea of these results , we state here a particular case .",
    "let us take @xmath46 .",
    "then @xmath28 $ ] is isomorphic to the ring of formal power series in @xmath47 variables .",
    "let @xmath44 be an ideal of the ring @xmath27 $ ] of formal power series in @xmath47 variables over an arbitrary field @xmath9 endowed with the trivial valuation .",
    "then :    1 .",
    "the finite part of the local positive tropicalization @xmath48 of the ideal @xmath44 ( that is , of the natural morphism from @xmath1 to the quotient local ring @xmath49/i$ ] ) is the support of a finite rational polyhedral fan in @xmath50 .",
    "if @xmath44 is prime and @xmath51/i$ ] has krull dimension @xmath52 , then @xmath48 has pure dimension @xmath52 .",
    "3 .   if @xmath44 is the formal completion of the localization at @xmath53 of an ideal @xmath54 of the polynomial ring @xmath55 $ ] , then the local positive tropicalization @xmath48 coincides with the global tropicalization @xmath56 of the subvariety of the torus defined by @xmath54 inside the open cone @xmath57 .",
    "the last point of the theorem shows that it is possible to reconstruct the ( global ) tropicalization of a subvariety of a torus from local tropicalizations of its closure at the closed points of various toric varieties associated to that torus . in this sense ,",
    "global tropicalization depends only on the boundary structure of the subvariety of the torus .",
    "in fact , the local tropicalization of an ideal @xmath44 of @xmath28 $ ] depends only on the toroidal structure of the ambient space @xmath58 $ ] . in order to show this",
    ", we prove that , more generally , we can tropicalize semigroup morphisms of the form : @xmath59 where @xmath60 denotes the subgroup of invertible elements of @xmath61 .",
    "this allows , e.  g. , to tropicalize objects which are not necessarily endowed with a toroidal structure :    * if @xmath62 is a germ of normal ( algebraic or analytic ) variety and @xmath63 is a reduced weil divisor on it , consider a finitely generated semigroup @xmath1 of effective cartier divisors supported on @xmath63 .",
    "then , taking @xmath64 , we have a natural semigroup morphism @xmath65 , obtained by associating to each cartier divisor a defining function in @xmath0 , which is well - defined modulo units .",
    "* we keep the same setting as in the previous example and let @xmath1 be the full semigroup of effective cartier divisors supported on @xmath63 .",
    "then we obtain a canonical tropicalization for each ideal @xmath44 of @xmath66 associated to the pair @xmath67 , by taking @xmath68 and the natural semigroup morphism @xmath65 given by composing the map of the previous example with the map @xmath69 induced by the quotient morphism @xmath70 .",
    "these examples should be useful for the local study of weil divisors on algebraic or analytic varieties , in such simple cases as those of germs of plane curves .",
    "in particular , they should allow to understand tropically a good amount of combinatorial invariants of singularities , for instance those extracted from weighted dual graphs of resolutions or embedded resolutions .",
    "each section in this paper begins with a brief description of its content .",
    "the comparison with the existing literature on the subject is concentrated in the last section , which also contains a brief description of possible interactions with developing fields of mathematics and two open problems .",
    "the first author has benefited a lot from conversations with anglica cueto , charles favre and anders jensen and the second one from discussions with mark spivakovsky .",
    "we are grateful to pedro d. gonzlez prez , hussein mourtada and bernard teissier for their remarks on previous versions of this paper .",
    "last but not least , we thank heartedly the two anonymous referees for their very careful reading and for their many suggestions for clarification .",
    "in this section we introduce the vocabulary and basic facts about semigroups that we shall use in this paper .",
    "[ defsg ] a * semigroup * is a set @xmath1 endowed with an associative binary operation @xmath71 .",
    "_ in the sequel , we shall consider only _ commutative _ semigroups_. the simplest examples are abelian groups , but semigroups are interesting precisely because of the existence of elements which are not invertible .",
    "if a semigroup has a neutral element @xmath53 , then we call it a semigroup _ with origin_. if it has an @xmath72 element ( also called _ absorbing _ ) , that is , an element which is unchanged by the addition of any other element , then it is called a semigroup _ with infinity_. we see immediately that , if they exist , then the origin and the infinity are unique .",
    "if the semigroup law is thought multiplicatively then , by analogy with @xmath73 , the origin is denoted @xmath18 and the infinity is denoted @xmath53 ( see for example @xcite ) , and we speak sometimes about semigroups _ with identity _ and _ with zero_. nevertheless , in the sequel we are consequent with the previous terminology and we say that , when @xmath74 is a ring , then @xmath53 _ is the infinity of _ the semigroup @xmath61 .",
    "if a semigroup @xmath1 has no origin , then we may canonically add such element to it , obtaining the semigroup with origin @xmath75 .",
    "if it has no infinity , we can analogously add to it a new element @xmath72 , getting @xmath76 .",
    "[ gensg ] a semigroup is called * cancellative * if , whenever @xmath77 satisfy @xmath78 , we have @xmath79 .",
    "it is called * of finite type * if it can be generated by a finite number of elements .",
    "it is called * torsion - free * if whenever @xmath80 and @xmath81 for some @xmath82 , we have @xmath83 .",
    "note that a semigroup with infinity is not cancellative , excepted in the degenerate case when it has only one element , which is necessarily both the origin and the infinity .",
    "the following type of semigroups will play an essential role in our paper :    [ toricsg ] a semigroup with origin @xmath84 is called * affine * if it is commutative , of finite type , cancellative and torsion - free .",
    "the simplest affine semigroups are the various @xmath85 .",
    "the terminology `` _ _ affine _ _ '' is motivated by the fact that those are precisely the semigroups associated to _ affine _",
    "toric varieties ( see the next section and @xcite ) .",
    "consider a semigroup @xmath1 with origin . if @xmath86 , an _ inverse _ of @xmath87 is an element @xmath88 such that @xmath89 . if it exists , the inverse of @xmath87 is unique and we denote it simply by @xmath90 .",
    "the set of invertible elements is a subgroup of @xmath1 , which we denote @xmath91 .",
    "we let @xmath92 be its complement in @xmath1 .",
    "it is a prime ideal of @xmath1 ( see lemma [ primid ] ) , in agreement with the next definition :    [ sgideal ] if @xmath1 is a semigroup , an * ideal * of @xmath1 is a subset @xmath93 satisfying @xmath94 . an ideal is called * proper * if @xmath95 .",
    "the ideal @xmath44 is * prime * if it is proper and , whenever @xmath96 satisfy @xmath97 , then at least one of @xmath98 is in @xmath44 .",
    "this vocabulary is motivated by the following fundamental example of semigroups :    [ multring ] let @xmath99 be a commutative ring . forgetting the addition , @xmath100 is a semigroup with origin @xmath101 .",
    "@xmath102 is cancellative if and only if @xmath0 is a domain .",
    "any ideal @xmath44 of the ring @xmath99 is an ideal of the semigroup @xmath61 .",
    "the converse is not true , as we do not ask for stability of the operation @xmath103 in the semigroup - theoretical definition of an ideal .",
    "for example , if @xmath104 , the semigroup - ideal generated by @xmath105 and @xmath106 is the set of integers divisible either by @xmath105 or by @xmath106 , which is not a ring - ideal .",
    "[ primid ] the subsemigroup @xmath92 of non - invertible elements of @xmath1 is a prime ideal of @xmath1 .",
    "let us first verify that @xmath92 is an ideal .",
    "suppose that @xmath107 and @xmath88 satisfy @xmath108 .",
    "this means that there exists @xmath109 such that @xmath110 . but",
    "this can be rewritten by associativity as @xmath111 , which shows that @xmath112 , a contradiction .",
    "therefore , @xmath113 , which is the definition of the fact that @xmath92 is an ideal .",
    "the fact that this ideal is prime is immediate , consequence of the fact that @xmath91 is stable under addition .",
    "it is a formal exercise to see that the preimage of an ideal by a morphism of semigroups is again an ideal and that , moreover , in this way , prime ideals are transformed into prime ideals .",
    "notice also that each semigroup @xmath1 with origin is _ local _ , in the sense that it contains a unique maximal ideal @xmath92 .    in ring theory ,",
    "ideals are precisely the kernels of the ring - morphisms .",
    "this is not true for semigroups . in order to speak about this phenomenon",
    ", we introduce basic notation about morphisms of semigroups .",
    "if @xmath114 and @xmath115 are semigroups , we denote by : @xmath116 the set of morphisms of semigroups from @xmath114 to @xmath115 .",
    "analogously , if @xmath117 and @xmath118 are two rings , we denote by : @xmath119 the set of ring - morphisms .    _",
    "if both semigroups @xmath114 and @xmath115 have origins , we assume that a morphism of semigroups sends one origin into the other .",
    "_ @xmath120 has also naturally a structure of semigroup , by pointwise addition of the values .",
    "let @xmath121 be a morphism of semigroups with origins .",
    "its set - theoretic image @xmath122 is a subsemigroup of @xmath115 and its kernel @xmath123 is a subsemigroup of @xmath114 ( in general it is not an ideal ; that is , from this viewpoint , semigroups behave more like groups than like rings ) .",
    "nevertheless , unlike for abelian groups , the knowledge of this kernel is not enough to determine the associated surjective map @xmath124 up to isomorphism .",
    "indeed , the fact that not all elements are invertible does not allow to conclude from @xmath125 that @xmath87 is obtained from @xmath126 by adding an element of the kernel .",
    "briefly said , in general the kernel does not describe _ all _ the fibers of the map @xmath127 .    in order to be able to reconstruct the whole map @xmath128",
    ", we have to encode the whole collection of its fibers .",
    "this may be done by looking at them as the equivalence classes of an equivalence relation @xmath129 .",
    "this equivalence relation on @xmath114 is _ compatible with the addition _ , so it is a _ congruence _ :    [ congr ] let @xmath84 be a semigroup with origin .",
    "a * congruence * on @xmath1 is an equivalence relation compatible with the addition .",
    "if @xmath129 is a congruence on @xmath1 , we see immediately that the addition on @xmath1 descends naturally to a semigroup law on the quotient @xmath130 , the quotient map becoming a morphism of semigroups with origin .    for instance",
    ", the relation defined by @xmath131 is a congruence .",
    "it allows to define the quotient semigroup @xmath132 .",
    "to any commutative semigroup @xmath1 with origin , one functorially associates _ the group _",
    "@xmath133 generated formally by the differences of its elements : @xmath134    the canonical morphism of semigroups @xmath135 is an embedding if and only if @xmath1 is cancellative .",
    "indeed , it is an embedding if and only if it is injective , which is equivalent to the fact that for any @xmath136 , the equality @xmath137 implies that @xmath138 . but",
    "this is precisely the condition of cancellation ! for example , when @xmath139 this gives the canonical inclusion @xmath140 .",
    "assuming @xmath1 to be cancellative , it is moreover torsion - free if and only if @xmath133 is a torsion - free abelian group . indeed ,",
    "if there exists @xmath141 and @xmath86 such that @xmath142 , then there exists @xmath109 such that @xmath143 . as @xmath1 is cancellative , we deduce that @xmath144 .",
    "as @xmath1 is torsion - free , we conclude that @xmath145 .",
    "on the other hand , it is not true that @xmath1 is of finite type if and only if @xmath133 is of finite type .",
    "for instance , @xmath146 is of finite type but @xmath147 is not of finite type .",
    "only the following implication holds : if @xmath1 is of finite type , then so is @xmath133 .",
    "we define a _ lattice _ as an abelian torsion - free group of finite type .",
    "the previous explanations have as a direct consequence the following characterization of affine semigroups :    a semigroup is affine if and only if it is a finitely generated subsemigroup of a lattice and it has an origin .",
    "let @xmath1 be an affine semigroup and @xmath133 be its associated lattice .",
    "we denote by @xmath148 the dual lattice .",
    "[ satur ] the * saturation * @xmath149 of @xmath1 ( inside @xmath133 ) is the subset of @xmath133 formed by the elements @xmath150 satisfying @xmath151 for some @xmath141 .",
    "a semigroup is called * saturated * if it is equal to its saturation .",
    "[ nonsatex ] let us consider the affine subsemigroup @xmath1 of @xmath152 generated by @xmath153 ( see figure [ fig : affsg ] ) .",
    "the associated lattice @xmath133 is equal to @xmath154 , and @xmath155 is @xmath152 . as is visible in the drawing",
    ", @xmath91 is the subgroup of @xmath156 generated by @xmath157 . in the drawing",
    "is also represented the quotient map @xmath158 .",
    "this last semigroup @xmath159 is isomorphic to the image of @xmath1 by the canonical projection of @xmath152 to the first factor @xmath160 .",
    "therefore it is affine .    at 36 294 at 96 332 at 150 314 at 37 349 at 37 240 at -10 130 at 234 78 at 34 7     [ nonsatexbis ] in the previous example ,",
    "the quotient @xmath132 was again affine .",
    "this is not true for all affine semigroups @xmath1 .",
    "consider for instance the affine subsemigroup of @xmath154 generated by @xmath161 ( see figure [ fig : affsgtor ] ) .",
    "then @xmath91 is the lattice of rank one generated by @xmath157 .",
    "the quotient @xmath132 has torsion , as the images @xmath162 and @xmath163 are different ( there does not exist any @xmath164 such that @xmath165 ) but their doubles are equal ( as @xmath166 ) . in fact , the restriction to @xmath1 of the second projection @xmath167 factors through the quotient map @xmath168 , inducing a map @xmath169 .",
    "the fibers @xmath170 of this map have two points for @xmath171 , only the origin being covered by one point .",
    "that is why we represented the @xmath132 as the set @xmath160 in which every positive number is split into two points .    at 36 294 at 106 350 at 103 286 at 28 372 at 37 227 at -10 180 at 234 78 at 34 7     the situation of",
    "the previous example can not happen for saturated affine semigroups :    [ quotaff ] if the affine semigroup @xmath1 is saturated , then @xmath132 is also a saturated affine semigroup .    if @xmath86 , denote by @xmath172 its image in @xmath173 . as a quotient of a commutative semigroup of finite type , @xmath174 is also commutative and of finite type .",
    "let us show that @xmath174 is _",
    "cancellative_. suppose that @xmath175 satisfy the equality @xmath176 .",

    "that is , @xmath174 is also cancellative .",

    "saturated_. the previous argument shows that @xmath91 is a primitive sublattice of @xmath133 , that is , that the quotient @xmath192 is torsion - free .",
    "as the images of the generators of @xmath1 also generate this quotient , we deduce that @xmath192 is canonically isomorphic to @xmath193 .",
    "we will work with this representative of the associated lattice .",
    "consider therefore @xmath194 such that there exists @xmath195 and @xmath86 with @xmath196 in @xmath192 .",

    "until now we have only discussed algebraic aspects of semigroups .",
    "we now describe their topology .",
    "suppose that the semigroup @xmath1 _ has no infinity _ and moreover _ is totally ordered _ ,",
    "that is , it is endowed with a total order compatible with the addition .",
    "then , we can equip @xmath1 with a natural topology generated by the `` open '' intervals .",
    "we extend this topology to @xmath76 by taking as basis of neighborhoods of @xmath72 the subsets of the form : @xmath201:= \\{x \\in \\gamma \\ |",
    "\\      x > a \\ }",
    "\\cup \\ { \\infty \\}.\\ ] ]    note that with this convention , @xmath202 , not @xmath203 .",
    "we will mainly use the previous construction of topology when @xmath1 is @xmath204 , @xmath205 , @xmath206 , @xmath207 , @xmath160 , the semigroup operation beeing addition .",
    "this section is intended only to set the notations we use for toric geometry . for details on _ normal _ toric varieties , we refer to fulton s book @xcite . for",
    "not necessarily normal toric varieties , the reader can consult the recent monograph @xcite of cox , little , and schenck , or gonzalez prez and teissier s paper @xcite .    in the sequel ,",
    "if @xmath208 is an abelian group and @xmath9 is a field , we will denote by @xmath209 the @xmath9-vector space @xmath210 .",
    "let @xmath1 be an affine smigroup .",
    "we denote by : @xmath211 the finite rational polyhedral cone generated by @xmath1 . by definition ,",
    "it consists of all the combinations with nonnegative real coefficients of elements of @xmath1 .",
    "it is a sub - cone of the real vector space @xmath212 with non - empty interior .",
    "the saturation of @xmath1 may be described geometrically using the cone @xmath213 : @xmath214    we denote by @xmath215 the dual cone , defined by : @xmath216    more generally , if @xmath217 is a polyhedral cone in a finite dimensional real vector space @xmath7 and @xmath218 is its dual cone in the dual space @xmath219 , then @xmath220 and the map : @xmath221 establishes an inclusion - reversing bijection between the closed faces of @xmath217 and those of @xmath218 .",
    "the cone @xmath218 has non - empty interior if and only if @xmath217 is _ strictly convex _ , that is , if it does not contain any vector subspace of positive dimension .",
    "we will say also in this case that @xmath217 is a _ pointed cone_. if @xmath222 , we say that @xmath1 is a _ pointed semigroup_. it is immediate to check that the affine semigroup @xmath1 is pointed if and only if the cone @xmath213 is pointed .",
    "the vocabulary introduced in the following definition is taken from @xcite :    if @xmath1 is an affine semigroup , then a * face * of @xmath1 is a subsemigroup @xmath223 such that whenever @xmath224 satisfy @xmath225 , then both @xmath226 and @xmath227 are in @xmath228 .",
    "the following proposition characterizes the faces of @xmath1 :    [ faces ] the faces of @xmath1 are precisely the complements of the prime ideals of @xmath1 .",
    "the map @xmath229 establishes an inclusion - reversing bijection between the faces of @xmath230 and those of @xmath1 .    in the sequel ,",
    "if @xmath1 is affine and @xmath231 is a face of @xmath230 , we denote : @xmath232 if @xmath233 denotes the sublattice of @xmath234 spanned by @xmath235 , the quotient @xmath236 is canonically dual to @xmath237 , i.e. , @xmath238 .",
    "the subgroup @xmath91 of invertible elements is the _ minimal _ face , in the sense that it is contained in all the other ones . by the previous bijection",
    ", it corresponds to @xmath239 .",
    "let @xmath1 be an affine semigroup and @xmath9 be a field .",
    "we denote by : @xmath240\\ ] ] the associated _ toric variety _ defined over @xmath9 .",
    "its @xmath9-_valued points _ are naturally identified with the semigroup : @xmath241 , k ) \\simeq \\operatorname{hom}_{sg}((\\gamma , + ) , ( k , \\cdot)).\\ ] ] notice that the multiplicative semigroup @xmath242 has @xmath53 as infinity .",
    "when @xmath1 is of the form @xmath243 , and @xmath217 is a strictly convex rational polyhedral cone in the real vector space @xmath244 , we define : @xmath245 these are precisely the _ normal _ affine toric varieties .    in the same way as abstract varieties over a field",
    "are obtained by gluing affine cones , we can glue affine toric varieties by respecting the ambient structure , that is , the action of the torus @xmath246 $ ] .",
    "this is easiest to describe in the case of normal toric varieties : the combinatorial object encoding the gluing is a _",
    "fan_.    a * fan * in @xmath244 is a finite set @xmath247 of convex polyhedral cones inside @xmath244 , such that :    \\a ) for each cone @xmath217 in @xmath247 , all its faces are in @xmath247 ;    \\b ) if @xmath248 and @xmath249 are cones of @xmath247 , then @xmath250 is a common face .",
    "if all the cones are rational , that is , they are defined as the intersections of halfspaces @xmath251 , where @xmath252 and @xmath253 is the pairing between @xmath234 and @xmath254 , then the fan is called * rational*.    these conditions imply that all the cones in @xmath247 have a maximal common linear suspace .",
    "we say that @xmath247 is a _ pointed fan _ ,",
    "if this linear subspace is the origin , that is , if all the cones of @xmath247 are _ strictly convex_.",
    "if @xmath247 is a pointed finite rational polyhedral fan inside @xmath244 , we denote by @xmath255 the normal toric variety over the field @xmath9 associated to the lattice @xmath234 and the fan @xmath247",
    ". it is obtained by the usual gluing of affine toric varieties : @xmath256 and @xmath257 are glued along @xmath258 , which is an open affine toric subvariety of both of them ( see @xcite or @xcite ) .    there is an incidence - reversing bijection between the cones of @xmath247 and the orbits of the torus action on @xmath255 .",
    "we denote by @xmath259 the orbit associated to the cone @xmath260 .",
    "it is canonically identified with the torus @xmath261 .",
    "we may also encode combinatorially the gluing of not necessarily normal affine toric varieties , as explained by gonzlez prez and teissier in @xcite .",
    "for this , we propose the following new notion :    [ sgfan ] a * fan of semigroups * @xmath262 in @xmath234 is a rational fan @xmath247 in @xmath244 , enriched with an affine subsemigroup @xmath263 of @xmath1 for each cone @xmath264 , with the property that :    \\i ) for each cone @xmath265 in @xmath247 , @xmath266 and @xmath267 ;    \\ii ) if @xmath268 is a face of @xmath264 , then @xmath269 .    note that condition i ) implies that the fan @xmath247 is pointed .",
    "these conditions allow to glue the affine toric varieties @xmath270 corresponding to the various semigroups of a given fan of semigroups @xmath262 .",
    "we denote by @xmath271 the associated toric variety .",
    "in this section we develop a theory of embeddings of topological semigroups into bigger stratified topological spaces endowed with an action of the initial semigroup .",
    "this generalizes a construction introduced by ash , mumford , rapoport , tai ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* i.1 ) and developed recently by payne @xcite and kajiwara @xcite .",
    "their setting corresponds to the case when the semigroup is a strictly convex cone in a finite dimensional real vector space .",
    "recall that we assume all the semigroups to be commutative and with origin .",
    "let @xmath208 and @xmath272 be semigroups , and denote by : @xmath273 the semigroup of semigroup morphisms from @xmath208 to @xmath272 .",
    "we think about it as the set of @xmath272-_valued points _ of the semigroup @xmath208 .",
    "moreover , when @xmath272 is a topological semigroup , we endow @xmath274 with the _ topology of pointwise convergence _ , that is , the induced topology coming from the natural embedding @xmath275 , the target space being endowed with the product topology .    [ sgpoints ] when @xmath208 is an affine semigroup and @xmath272 is the multiplicative group @xmath276 of a field @xmath9 , then @xmath274 equals the torus @xmath277 , whose lattice of characters is the lattice @xmath278 associated to @xmath208 .",
    "the torus @xmath277 is naturally an algebraic variety and bears the zariski topology .",
    "if there is some natural topology on @xmath9 , the topology of pointwise convergence on @xmath277 is different from the zariski topology .",
    "when @xmath208 is either an affine semigroup or a polyhedral cone and @xmath272 is the additive group @xmath279 , then @xmath274 is the real vector space @xmath280 .",
    "this notation was explained before in the case of affine semigroups .",
    "when @xmath208 is a cone @xmath218 , @xmath280 denotes the dual space to the vector space @xmath281 generated by @xmath218 .",
    "notice that the functor @xmath282 is contravariant in the variable @xmath208 and covariant in the variable @xmath272 ( this is , of course , valid in any category ) .",
    "when @xmath272 has no infinity , we get in particular a natural embedding of semigroups : @xmath283    [ linvarsg ] if @xmath208 is a semigroup and @xmath272 a semigroup without infinity , we say that @xmath284 is the @xmath272-*valued ( affine ) linear variety of * @xmath208 .",
    "[ reasonlin ] we chose this name in analogy with that of _ toric varieties_. indeed , when @xmath208 is an affine semigroup and @xmath285 , as in example [ sgpoints ] , @xmath286 , is the set of @xmath9-valued points of the affine toric variety @xmath287 ( see formula ) .",
    "the attribute `` _ _ toric _ _ '' makes reference to a natural action of an algebraic ( split ) torus , whose law is thought of multiplicatively . in our context , the analog of the torus is the semigroup @xmath274 , thought of additively .",
    "it acts naturally on the linear variety @xmath284 .",
    "the most important case for us is @xmath288 , when @xmath274 is a vector spce .",
    "this explains the attribute `` _ _ linear _ _ '' in our terminology . in what concerns",
    "the attribute `` affine '' , it makes reference to the fact that we define an analog of the notion of _ affine _ toric variety .",
    "assume now that @xmath272 is a group .",
    "in the same way as toric varieties are canonically stratified into the orbits of the associated torus , the linear variety @xmath284 is stratified into the orbits of the natural action of @xmath274 on @xmath284 induced by the addition @xmath289 on the values . for an affine @xmath208 and divisible @xmath272 ,",
    "these orbits may be described in a different way , using the notion of prime ideal of a semigroup ( see definition [ sgideal ] ) :    let @xmath272 be a divisible group and @xmath208 an affine semigroup .",
    "the orbits of the natural action of @xmath274 on @xmath284 are in a bijection with the prime ideals of @xmath208 .",
    "the bijection is given by : @xmath290    therefore , those orbits are in natural bijection with the faces of @xmath208 ( see proposition  [ faces ] ) . if @xmath291 is a fan of affine semigroups and @xmath272 is a divisible group , then we have the canonical identification @xmath292 , where @xmath293 and @xmath133 is the same lattice for all the semigroups @xmath293 , by condition i ) of definition  [ sgfan ] .    [ remlin ] the construction of ( * ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* i.1 ) alluded to in the introductory paragraph of this section , and developed further by payne @xcite and kajiwara @xcite , corresponds to the case when @xmath208 is a saturated affine semigroup @xmath294 and @xmath295 ( see again example [ sgpoints ] ) .",
    "we chose to develop this more general categorical viewpoint for the following reasons :    1 .   to get extra structures on @xmath296 from the functorial properties of our construction .",
    "for instance , when @xmath208 is affine , then , the integral points of @xmath297 are the points in @xmath298 .",
    "2 .   to study also valuations taking values in totally ordered groups which do not embed into @xmath204 , that is , which have rank at least @xmath105 . for instance , this could be useful when developing the theory initiated by f. aroca in @xcite .",
    "we focus now on the topological aspects of the constructions .",
    "let @xmath208 be a saturated affine semigroup @xmath294 , @xmath295 , @xmath299 is a strictly convex rational polyhedral cone .",
    "fix : @xmath300    @xmath301    whenever @xmath234 is clear from the context , we omit it and denote @xmath302 simpy by @xmath303 .",
    "we denote by @xmath304 the subspace of @xmath303 consisting of those semigroup morphisms @xmath305 which take only positive values ( possibly @xmath306 ) on the maximal ideal of the semigroup @xmath243 .",
    "we say that @xmath304 is the _ interior _ of @xmath303 .",
    "we view @xmath307 as a space of functions from the set @xmath294 to the topological space @xmath308 , and endow it with the topology of pointwise convergence .",
    "this is the weakest topology for which all the sets @xmath309 are open , where @xmath310 and @xmath311 is an open subset of @xmath308 .",
    "since the topological space @xmath308 is separated , this topology is also separated .",
    "since @xmath204 is a dense open subspace of @xmath308 , we see that @xmath244 is also a dense open subspace of @xmath307 .",
    "respecting the conventions of definition [ linvarsg ] , we introduce the following terminology :    [ linvardef ] the topological space @xmath307 , endowed with the natural continuous action @xmath312 extending the action of @xmath244 on itself by translations is called * the affine linear variety * associated to the pair @xmath313 .",
    "we say that the closure of the cone @xmath217 in @xmath307 is the * extended cone * @xmath303 .    the affine linear variety @xmath307 is obtained by adding to the vector space @xmath244 some strata _ at infinity _ , each stratum being by definition an orbit of the previous action .",
    "these strata have a canonical structure of vector spaces , in the same way as the orbits of the canonical action of a torus on an associated affine toric variety are canonically lower - dimensional tori .",
    "more precisely , they are canonically identified with the vector spaces @xmath314 , where @xmath231 is a face of the cone @xmath217 ( including @xmath53 and @xmath217 itself ) . here",
    ", @xmath233 denotes the intersection of the vector space spanned by @xmath231 with the lattice @xmath234 .",
    "we now introduce a topology on the disjoint union @xmath315 . if @xmath311 is an open subset of @xmath244 and @xmath316",

    "@xmath361 , the system of fans @xmath406 has the following interpretation :    the system of fans @xmath406 gives a stratification of the subspace @xmath407 of the affine linear variety @xmath361 : @xmath408    notice that the subspace @xmath304 consists of the interior @xmath409 of @xmath217 and all projections of @xmath409 to the strata @xmath410 and it is indeed the interior of @xmath303 in the usual topological sense .",
    "moreover , if @xmath231 is a face of @xmath217 , we define the _ relative interior @xmath411 of @xmath231 inside @xmath303 _ to be the union of the usual relative interior @xmath412 of @xmath231 and all projections of @xmath412 to the strata @xmath413 , where @xmath414 is a face of @xmath231 .",
    "we could have easily avoided using the lattice @xmath234 and the rationality of the fan @xmath247 for the construction of the linear variety @xmath415 ( for instance , we could have defined @xmath416 as the set of semigroup morphisms from @xmath218 to @xmath417 which are equivariant under the natural action of @xmath418 ) .",
    "in fact , these discrete data determine an additional _ integral structure _ on the linear variety , as a particular case of remark [ remlin ] , ( 2 ) :    if @xmath247 is a rational polyhedral fan , then every stratum @xmath405 of the linear variety @xmath399 carries a lattice @xmath419 in such a way that the natural action of @xmath234 on itself extends canonically to an action by addition of @xmath234 on all the lattices @xmath419 , @xmath420 .",
    "if we consider as starting data of the construction a fan of semigroups @xmath262 ( see definition [ sgfan ] ) , instead of simply the underlying fan of cones @xmath247 , the supplementary structure induced on @xmath399 is the knowledge , for each stratum at infinity @xmath405 , of the semigroup @xmath421 , seen as a special additive semigroup of linear functions on @xmath234 .",
    "in this section we present the material from valuation theory we need in the sequel .",
    "we will work only with valuations taking values in the extended real line @xmath308 .",
    "[ ringval ] let @xmath0 be a ring .",
    "a * real ( ring ) valuation * on @xmath0 is a map @xmath422 such that :    1 .",
    "@xmath20 is a morphism of semigroups from @xmath423 to @xmath424 .",
    "2 .   @xmath425 and @xmath426 .",
    "3 .   @xmath427 , for all @xmath428 .",
    "the _ trivial valuation _ is the valuation on an integral domain which vanishes identically on @xmath429 .",
    "in general , valuations take values in arbitrary totally ordered abelian groups extended by @xmath72 ( see zariski and samuel s book @xcite , as well as vaqui s introductory text @xcite ) . as we will not use that level of generality , in the sequel by _ valuation _ we mean a real ring valuation .",
    "the following is an immediate consequence of the definition :    [ imcomp ] if @xmath430 , @xmath20 is a valuation of @xmath0 , and @xmath431 , then @xmath432 .",
    "we denote by @xmath3 the set of valuations on @xmath0 , endowed with the topology of pointwise convergence of maps from @xmath0 to @xmath308 .",
    "we call it * the valuation space of * @xmath0 .",
    "recall that the topology of pointwise convergence is generated by the subsets of the form : @xmath433 in the sense that its open sets are arbitrary unions of finite intersections of such sets ( one says that these sets form a _",
    "subbasis _ of the topology ) .",
    "any morphism of rings @xmath434 induces , by composition , a function between the associated valuation spaces : @xmath435    [ valfunc ] the function @xmath436 is continuous .",
    "therefore , @xmath437 defines a contravariant functor from the category of rings to the category of topological spaces .",
    "consider an arbitrary subbasic open subset @xmath438 of @xmath439 , where @xmath440 and @xmath311 is open in @xmath308 .",
    "then its pre ] is , by definition , an open subset of @xmath3 .",
    "this shows that our map @xmath436 is continuous .",
    "we say that a valuation @xmath441 * is centered in * @xmath0 if @xmath442 for every @xmath443 .",
    "in this case the * center * of the valuation @xmath20 is the prime ideal @xmath444 .",
    "the * home * of the valuation @xmath20 is the prime ideal @xmath445 .",
    "the home of a valuation is characterized by the following lemma :    [ homechar ] a valuation @xmath446 is the preimage of a valuation @xmath447 if and only if the ideal @xmath44 is contained in the home of @xmath20 .",
    "classically ( see zariski and samuel s book @xcite ) , the definition of valuations requires that non - zero elements take values in @xmath204 .",
    "therefore , a valuation in the extended sense which we use in this paper is simply obtained by pulling back a classical valuation from a quotient ring .",
    "we need such extended valuations , as they may appear as limits of classical ones .",
    "since we work with valuations centered in a ring @xmath0 , we do not need to add more points to the valuation space , as the next proposition shows .",
    "[ compactness ] the space @xmath448 of valuations centered in @xmath0 is compact .    by tychonoff s theorem ( see for instance ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* section 1 - 10 ) ) , the space @xmath449^r$ ] is compact when endowed with the product topology .",
    "therefore it is enough to prove that @xmath448 is closed inside @xmath449^r$ ] .",
    "but any function in @xmath449^r$ ] which is a limit of valuations is also a valuation . indeed ,",
    "the axioms of definition [ ringval ] depend on at most two elements of @xmath0 , and those equalities or inequalities are preserved by the limit process .",
    "the previous proof is similar to zariski s proof of the quasi - compactness of the rieman - zariski space @xmath450 of a field extension @xmath451 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "vi , sect .",
    "17 , theorem 40 ) ) . by definition , the points of this space are the krull - valuation rings of @xmath9 containing @xmath452 .",
    "the topology of @xmath450 is obtained by taking as basis of open sets the subsets of valuation rings which contain a given finitely generated subring of @xmath9 containing @xmath452 . in order to get the announced quasi - compactness , zariski embeds @xmath450 in the space of maps from @xmath9 to @xmath453 ( associating to each element of @xmath9 the sign of its value ) .",
    "then he uses tychonoff s theorem for the space @xmath454 .",
    "a subtle point here is that in order to apply tychonoff s theorem we must use the discrete topology on @xmath453 ( making it hausdorff compact ) , but in order to get the correct topology on @xmath450 we have to consider a weaker topology ( having the full set and @xmath455 as basis of open sets ) , which is non - hausdorff .    in the sequel",
    ", we will need to work with special subspaces of the valuation space of a ring .",
    "in addition to the spaces @xmath448 introduced in proposition  [ compactness ] , the main types of subspaces we need are described in the next two definitions .",
    "[ valrel ] let @xmath456 be a morphism of rings and let @xmath457 be a fixed valuation . denote by @xmath458 the set of valuations @xmath459 on @xmath0 such that @xmath460 .",
    "we call it * the valuation space of @xmath0 relative to * @xmath461 .",
    "when @xmath450 is a subring of @xmath0 and @xmath462 is the inclusion morphism , we also write : @xmath463 , and we call it * the valuation space of @xmath0 relative to * @xmath464 .",
    "[ explberk ] when @xmath450 is a subfield of @xmath0 and @xmath465 is a valuation such that @xmath450 is complete with respect to the associated norm @xmath466 , the relative valuation space @xmath467 is precisely the underlying topological space of the _ berkovich analytic space _ associated to @xmath468 ( see @xcite ) .",
    "one may consult gubler @xcite for relations between berkovich analytification and tropicalization .",
    "[ relideal ]",
    "let @xmath469 be a prime ideal of @xmath0 .",
    "denote by @xmath470 the subspace of @xmath3 consisting of all valuations centered in @xmath0 and whose center is precisely @xmath469 . call it * the valuation space of @xmath0 relative to @xmath469*.    any valuation @xmath471 extends to the localization @xmath472 by setting @xmath473 for @xmath474 and @xmath475 .",
    "moreover , in this way we get a valuation from @xmath476 . thus the spaces @xmath477 and @xmath476 are naturally homeomorphic .    as a particular case of the previous definition :    [ locval ] if @xmath35 is a local ring , we call @xmath478 the * space of local valuations * of @xmath35 .",
    "we recall that _ a local morphism _ @xmath479 between local rings is a morphism of rings such that @xmath480 . as a local analog of proposition [ valfunc ] ,",
    "we have :    [ valfuncloc ] let @xmath481 be a local morphism of local rings .",
    "then the canonical map @xmath482 is continuous .",
    "therefore , taking valuation spaces _ defines a contravariant functor from the category of local rings and local morphisms to the category of topological spaces_.    given a valuation @xmath20 on a ring @xmath0 , we define the associated value of an ideal @xmath44 : @xmath483 when @xmath0 is noetherian and @xmath20 is nonnegative on @xmath0 , any ideal is finitely generated , and the infimum is achieved , due to the following lemma :    [ valmin ] suppose that the ideal @xmath44 of the ring @xmath0 is generated by @xmath484 and let @xmath485 be a valuation center in @xmath0 .",
    "then : @xmath486    this lemma follows directly from the definition of valuations and from nonnegativity of @xmath20 on @xmath0 .",
    "now , let @xmath35 be a noetherian local ring and let @xmath487 be its completion with respect to @xmath37 .",
    "[ extcompl ] let @xmath488 .",
    "then @xmath20 is continuous with respect to the @xmath37-adic topology .",
    "it may therefore be extended by continuity to a valuation in @xmath489 .",
    "since the ring @xmath0 is noetherian , krull s theorem implies that it is separated in its @xmath37-adic topology , that is , @xmath490 ( see ( * ? ? ? * ; * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary 10.18 ) ) . using lemma [ valmin",
    "] , we see that : @xmath491.\\ ] ] the same lemma implies that @xmath492 , for all @xmath195 .",
    "consider any @xmath493 . by the definition of the @xmath37-adic topology , the sets @xmath494 form a basis of neighborhoods of @xmath495 .",
    "we consider now two cases , according to the value of @xmath496 .",
    "@xmath497 first , _ suppose that @xmath498_. then , there exists @xmath499 such that @xmath500 for any @xmath501 .",

    ", then we see that @xmath513 for all @xmath514 , which shows again that @xmath20 is continuous at @xmath495 .    as a consequence , we can canonically identifify the valuation space of a local noetherian ring with the one of its completion .",
    "[ c : completion ] the inclusion @xmath515 induces an isomorphism of local valuation spaces : @xmath516 .    by the previous lemma applied to @xmath487 ,",
    "any @xmath517 is continuous for the @xmath37-adic topology .",
    "therefore it is determined by its restriction to @xmath0 , which proves the injectivity of @xmath518 .",
    "the surjectivity follows from lemma  [ extcompl ] .",
    "the next lemma shows that we can reduce the study of the valuation space of an affine scheme to those of the irreducible components of the associated reduced scheme .",
    "[ redval ] let @xmath0 be a ring and @xmath519 be its reduction morphism ( that is , the morphism of quotient by its nilradical ) .",
    "then , the map @xmath520 induced by @xmath414 is a homeomorphism of @xmath3 and @xmath521 . if @xmath0 is reduced and the @xmath522 are the prime ideals of the primary decomposition of the zero ideal , then @xmath523 , that is , the valuation space of @xmath524 is the union of the valuation spaces of its irreducible components .",
    "the same holds for the space @xmath477 of valuations relative to a prime ideal @xmath469 of @xmath0 .",
    "the result follows from lemma [ homechar ] and the fact that if @xmath20 is a valuation of @xmath0 , then the home of @xmath20 contains necessarily at least one of the ideals @xmath525 of the primary decomposition of @xmath526 .",
    "in this section we describe our proposed framework for a theory of tropicalization which both generalizes the existing one of tropicalization of subvarieties of tori and allows in particular to tropicalize ( even formal ) germs of subvarieties of toric varieties .",
    "we stress also the functorial properties of our notion of tropicalization .",
    "the qualificative `` _ _ affine _ _ '' in the title of this section is explained in remark [ qualaffine ] . in section  [ s : extdef ]",
    "we describe a more general framework for functorial tropicalization .    in the sequel",
    ", @xmath84 denotes an arbitrary _ affine semigroup _ and @xmath99 a commutative ring .",
    "consider a _ morphism of semigroups _ : @xmath527 this is the same as giving a morphism of rings @xmath528 \\overset{\\gamma}{\\longrightarrow } r$ ] , and , thus , a morphism of schemes @xmath529)$ ] .",
    "if @xmath441 , we have @xmath530 . by formula ( [ aftt ] ) , we see that @xmath531 .",
    "we can define : @xmath532    it is a routine exercise to check :    [ l : contoftrop ] the map @xmath533 is continuous with respect to the topologies of pointwise convergence on @xmath3 and @xmath534 .    in the next definition ,",
    "we allow @xmath535 to be _ any _ subset of @xmath3 . in the sequel",
    "we will be particularly interested in these subsets of valuation spaces relative to valuations defined on subrings ( see definition [ valrel ] ) or to ideals ( see definition [ relideal ] ) .",
    "[ deftrop ] let @xmath6 be a subset of the valuation space @xmath3 .",
    "the closure in @xmath534 of the image @xmath536 is called * the ( global ) tropicalization of * @xmath535 * with respect to the semigroup morphism * @xmath5 , and it is denoted by @xmath537 or @xmath538 .",
    "[ caseekl ] one of the definitions of tropicalization of subvarieties of tori proposed by @xcite corresponds to the case where @xmath1 is the lattice of exponents of monomials of the torus @xmath539)$ ] , @xmath540 / i$ ] for an ideal @xmath44 of @xmath541 $ ] , @xmath5 is the composition @xmath542 \\rightarrow k[\\gamma ] / i$ ] , and @xmath543 is the set of valuations on @xmath0 extending a valuation @xmath150 of the field @xmath9 .",
    "our definition is indeed more general than the one explained in the previous remark .",
    "more precisely , if @xmath1 is an affine semigroup , and @xmath544 is a morphism of semigroups , then @xmath5 does not extend in general to a morphism from the associated lattice @xmath133 of @xmath1 .",
    "in fact , such an extension exists if and only if the image of @xmath5 is contained in the group of units of @xmath61 .",
    "[ specnot ] when @xmath9 is a field and @xmath44 is an ideal of the ring @xmath541 $ ] , we set : @xmath545 where @xmath546 / i$ ] and @xmath547 is the morphism of semigroups induced by the quotient map @xmath541 \\to k[\\gamma ] / i$ ] .",
    "when @xmath1 is saturated , this agrees with the notion of tropicalization of a subvariety of a normal affine toric variety introduced by payne @xcite .",
    "in fact , these tropicalizations may be glued to produce a tropicalization of an arbitrary subscheme of a general ( not necessarily normal ) toric variety . in this case , if the toric variety is clear from the context and @xmath23 is a subscheme of it , we denote this tropicalization simply by @xmath548 .",
    "next , we define the notion of _ local tropicalization_. denote by @xmath217 the cone @xmath549 .",

    "[ d : loctrop ] the * local positive tropicalization * of @xmath5 , denoted @xmath552 or simply @xmath553 , is the closure of the image of the map @xmath554 in the relative interior @xmath304 of the space @xmath303 .",
    "notice that in this definition we only consider those valuations of @xmath0 which have as center the closed point of @xmath524 . instead , if we only require that the valuations have a center on @xmath524 , possibly smaller than @xmath37 , we get another version of local tropicalization , which will also be important in the sequel :    [ d : nonnegtrop ] the * local nonnegative tropicalization * of @xmath5 , denoted @xmath555 , is the image in the extended cone @xmath303 of the map @xmath533 applied to all valuations of @xmath0 having a center on @xmath524 , that is , all nonnegative valuations of @xmath0 .",
    "the following proposition states direct consequences of the definitions of the two kinds of local tropicalizations :    [ p : closedtrop ] let @xmath1 be an arbitrary affine semigroup and @xmath556 .",
    "* the local nonnegative tropicalization is a closed subset of @xmath303 .",
    "* if the set @xmath557 , where @xmath92 is the maximal ideal of @xmath1 , generates @xmath37 ( as an ideal of the ring @xmath0 ) , then the image of the map @xmath558 coincides with @xmath559 . in particular , this image is closed in @xmath304 and @xmath560 .",
    "statement ( i ) follows from proposition  [ compactness ] and lemma  [ l : contoftrop ] .",
    "statement ( ii ) follows from ( i ) and the definition of positive tropicalization . in general",
    ", the question of closedness of the image of @xmath533 is subtler and connected to the problem of extension of valuations , see section  [ s : extval ] .",
    "[ specnotloc ] ( local analog of remark  [ specnot ] ) .",

    "let us now discuss the functorial properties of our definition of tropicalization ( both local and global ) .",
    "consider two semigroup morphisms @xmath571 , for @xmath572 .",
    "a * morphism from @xmath573 to @xmath574 * is a pair of maps : @xmath575 making the following diagram commutative : @xmath576^{\\phi_{h } }   &         r_2    \\\\",
    "\\gamma_1    \\ar[u]^{\\gamma_1 }   \\ar[r]_{\\lambda_{h } } &         \\gamma_2    \\ar[u]_{\\gamma_2 } } \\ ] ] we denote by _ * sgrg * _ the category defined in this way , and by _ * sgrgval * _ the category whose objects are pairs @xmath577 and whose morphisms are the morphisms of the category sgrg which respect the chosen subsets of the valuation spaces ( that is , which send one into the other ) .",
    "let @xmath578 , for @xmath572 be two objects of the category sgrgval and @xmath272 a morphism from @xmath579 to @xmath580 .",
    "then @xmath272 induces a functorial linear map : @xmath581 moreover , positive tropicalizations are preserved by @xmath582 .",
    "[ qualaffine ] we call the theory developed in this section `` affine '' , because we think about the category sgrgval as the analog of affine schemes",
    ". a next step , which we do not develop in this paper ( for some folow up on this matter , see sections  [ toroidal ] and [ s : extdef ] ) , would be to glue objects of this `` affine '' category into non - affine objects which may again be tropicalized .",
    "in this section we address the problem of extending of a valuation from a ring to a bigger ring , in a generality suitable for our purposes . as an application , we show that under convenient hypothesis , the real part of the local tropicalization is necessarily non - empty ( see lemma  [ l : finitepart ] ) , and that tropicalization is unchanged by passage to the normalization ( see corollary  [ c : normal ] ) .",
    "the following extension principle plays an important role in @xcite : if @xmath583 is a field extension and @xmath150 is a real valuation of @xmath9 , then @xmath150 can always be extended to a _ real _ valuation @xmath20 of @xmath339 , that is there is a real valuation @xmath20 of @xmath339 such that @xmath20 restricted to @xmath9 coincides with @xmath150 .",
    "we now give a local version of this extension principle .",
    "let @xmath35 and @xmath584 be two local rings such that @xmath585 , @xmath586 , and let @xmath150 be a local real ring valuation of the ring @xmath0 , i.e. , @xmath150 is nonnegative on @xmath0 and positive on the maximal ideal @xmath37 .",
    "we address the following question : _ does there exist a local real valuation @xmath20 of the ring @xmath450 such that @xmath20 restricted to @xmath0 coincides with @xmath150 ? _    as a first approach , we may assume that the given valuation @xmath150 is only nonnegative on @xmath37 , and ask whether there exists an extension @xmath20 nonnegative on @xmath587 .",
    "geometrically , we consider only valuations centered at the maximal ideals of our local rings , or , if @xmath150 and @xmath20 are only nonnegative on maximal ideals , such that their centers ( thought geometrically as irreducible subschemes ) contain the special points of @xmath524 and @xmath588 respectively . the answer to this question is not always positive , as shown by the following simple example .",
    "let @xmath589 $ ] , @xmath590 $ ] be two copies of the ring of formal power series in two variables over a field @xmath9 , and assume that the inclusion of @xmath0 into @xmath450 is given by the map @xmath591 , @xmath592 ( this corresponds to the blow up of a point in a plane ) .",
    "let @xmath150 be a monomial valuation on @xmath0 , trivial on @xmath9 , and determined by @xmath593 , @xmath594 .",
    "then @xmath150 can not be lifted to a local valuation @xmath20 of @xmath450 because @xmath20 must take value @xmath53 on @xmath595 . if we set @xmath596 , @xmath594 , then it is impossible to find a nonnegative extension @xmath20 , because @xmath597 must be equal to @xmath598 .",
    "next , we derive some sufficient conditions for the extension principle to hold .    [",
    "t : extprinciple ] let @xmath35 and @xmath584 be two local rings , @xmath585 , @xmath586 .",
    "let @xmath150 be a real nonnegative ring valuation on @xmath0 , and assume that one of the following conditions holds :    * @xmath450 is an integral extension of @xmath0 ( e.g. @xmath450 is a finite @xmath0-module ) ; * @xmath0 and @xmath450 are noetherian , complete with respect to the @xmath37-adic and @xmath587-adic topologies , and _ ( i ) _",
    "@xmath450 is flat over @xmath0 , _ ( ii ) _ the residue fields @xmath599 and @xmath600 are naturally isomorphic , and _ ( iii ) _ the fiber of the scheme @xmath601 over the maximal ideal @xmath37 of @xmath602 is reduced and irreducible , i.  e. , the ideal @xmath603 is prime in @xmath450 .",
    "then , there is a real nonnegative valuation @xmath20 of the ring @xmath450 such that @xmath20 restricted to @xmath0 coincides with @xmath150 . if , moreover , @xmath150 is local ( that is , positive on @xmath37 ) , then @xmath20 can also be chosen to be local .",
    "in fact , in case a ) every valuation @xmath20 extending @xmath150 is nonnegative , and local if @xmath150 is local .",

    "this finishes the proof of theorem  [ t : flatext ] .",
    "theorem  [ t : extprinciple ] may be expressed geometrically in the following way : _ any ( flat ) deformation of an algebroid germ over another such germ may be obtained as a finite ( ramified ) covering of the product of the base germ with a smooth algebroid variety .",
    "_    corollary  [ c : completion ] implies that when working with local tropicalization we can always pass to complete rings .",
    "note also that the positive tropicalization is never empty , since any local ring possesses the trivial local valuation @xmath150 , where @xmath679 if @xmath680 and @xmath681 if @xmath682 . under rather general assumptions on @xmath0 and some natural restrictions on @xmath5 the real part of the positive tropicalization is also nonempty .",

    "we show , essentially , that the tropicalization does not change if we pass to the normalization .",
    "[ l : normal ] let @xmath0 be an integral domain , @xmath687 a morphism from an affine semigroup @xmath1 , and @xmath450 the integral closure of @xmath0 in its field of fractions @xmath688 .",
    "then there exists a unique extension @xmath689 of @xmath5 , and : @xmath690 where @xmath3 and @xmath439 denote the spaces of all valuations of @xmath0 and of @xmath450 respectively . if @xmath0 and @xmath450 are both local , then also @xmath691 and @xmath692 .",
    "since none of the elements of @xmath1 goes to @xmath53 , the morphism @xmath5 extends uniquely to a homomorphism from @xmath133 to @xmath688 .",
    "but the images of elements of @xmath155 are obviously integral over @xmath0 , thus they belong to @xmath450 .",
    "any valuation of @xmath0 extends to a valuation of @xmath450 , and its values on @xmath155 are uniquely determined by its values on @xmath1 .",
    "moreover , by theorem  [ t : extprinciple ] , any nonnegative valuation of @xmath0 extends to a nonnegative valuation of @xmath450 .",
    "this implies all the equalities of tropicalizations .",
    "[ c : normal ] under the conditions of lemma  [ l : normal ] , assume that @xmath44 is an ideal of @xmath0 and @xmath44 is disjoint from the semigroup @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath693 and @xmath694 be the canonical projections . then",
    ": @xmath695 if @xmath0 and @xmath450 are both local , then @xmath696 , and similarly for the positive tropicalization .",
    "it suffices to show that if @xmath150 is a valuation of @xmath0 such that the home of @xmath150 contains @xmath44 , then the home of any extension @xmath697 of @xmath150 to @xmath450 contains @xmath698 .",
    "but indeed , if @xmath495 , @xmath699 and @xmath700 , then for any @xmath87 , @xmath701 we have @xmath702 .    [ reasnn ] in view of the previous results , the reader could wonder why we made the effort to develop a general framework of tropicalization for non - necessarily saturated affine semigroups .",
    "we see two reasons for this :    * even if we take a morphism between two normal affine toric varieties ( corresponding therefore to saturated affine semigroups ) , the closure of its image is again toric , but it may be non - normal .",
    "an example is given by the map from @xmath703 to @xmath704 defined by @xmath705 , which is a parametrization of the cuspidal plane cubic .",
    "as another example , consider the parametrization @xmath706 defined by @xmath707 of the whitney umbrella , defined by the equation @xmath708 in @xmath709 .",
    "* a morphism between two affine toric varieties does not necessarily lift to a morphism between their normalizations .",
    "for instance , consider the embedding of the singular locus of the whitney umbrella @xmath710 ( defined in the previous example ) into @xmath710 .",
    "this singular locus @xmath450 is the @xmath711-axis , therefore the embedding @xmath712 may be described as a restriction of the toric map @xmath713 given by @xmath714 .",
    "the morphism @xmath127 of the previous example is a normalization map of @xmath710 .",
    "the restriction of @xmath127 to @xmath715 is a double covering @xmath716 , therefore the map @xmath717 does not lift to a map from @xmath450 ( equal to its own normalization ) to the normalization @xmath704 of @xmath710 .",
    "in this section we explain basic properties of rings of formal power series over @xmath9 with exponents in pointed affine semigroups @xmath1 .",
    "we call them `` _ formal toric rings _ '' , as they are the completions of the rings of the affine toric varieties @xmath718 $ ] at the unique closed orbit .",
    "in fact , till corollary [ compldom ] we deal with arbitrary affine semigroups ( satisfying perhaps a technical condition , as in lemma [ l : fc ] ) .",
    "then we restrict to the pointed ones .",
    "let @xmath9 be a field and @xmath1 an affine semigroup ( see definition  [ toricsg ] ) .",
    "whenever we want to use multiplicative notation for the elements of the semigroup @xmath1 ( which happens when we look at them as _ monomials _ ) , we write @xmath719 instead of @xmath373 .",
    "we will say that @xmath373 is the _ exponent _ of the _ monomial _ @xmath719 .",
    "recall that @xmath91 denotes the subgroup of invertible elements of @xmath1 .",
    "they are related by the short semigroup exact sequence : @xmath720 where @xmath168 is the quotient map of the semigroup @xmath1 by the subgroup @xmath91 .    by proposition [ quotaff ] ,",
    "if @xmath1 is saturated , then @xmath174 is an affine semigroup .",
    "since its subgroup of units is trivial , @xmath174 is pointed .",
    "[ splitting ] suppose that the affine semigroup @xmath1 is saturated .",
    "then the morphism @xmath168 admits a section and any section induces a splitting of  .",
    "as explained in the proof of proposition [ quotaff ] , we have the following commutative diagram in which the horizontal lines are short exact sequences : @xmath721   &   \\gamma^ *   \\ar@{^{(}->}[d ] \\ar[r ] & \\gamma \\ar@{^{(}->}[d ] \\ar[r]^p &            \\gamma ' \\ar@{^{(}->}[d ]    \\ar[r ]   & 0    \\\\       0 \\ar[r ]   & \\gamma^ *    \\ar[r ] & m(\\gamma )    \\ar[r]^{m(p ) } &           m(\\gamma ' )    \\ar[r ]    & 0    } .\\ ] ] as @xmath193 is free , the surjective morphism of groups @xmath722 admits a section @xmath265 .",
    "this shows that the second exact sequence splits .",
    "let us restrict @xmath265 to @xmath174 .",
    "we see immediately that @xmath723 , which shows that @xmath265 is also a section of @xmath168 .",
    "define then the semigroup morphism @xmath724 by the formula @xmath725 .",
    "it is a routine exercise to check that it is an isomorphism of semigroups , and thus splits indeed .",
    "the previous proof shows that splits once we have a section of @xmath168 .",
    "this may happen also for non - saturated affine semigroups , as we see by starting from a product @xmath726 between a lattice @xmath91 and an arbitrary pointed affine semigroup @xmath174 .",
    "but such sections do not necessarily exist , as illustrated by examples [ nonsatex ] and [ nonsatexbis ] .",
    "the set of formal infinite sums : @xmath727 with naturally defined addition and multiplication , is called * the ring of formal power series over @xmath174 with coefficients in * @xmath728 .",
    "we denote it by @xmath729 $ ] .",
    "if @xmath339 is a field and @xmath1 is an affine semigroup , then the set @xmath730 $ ] of formal power series with exponents in @xmath1 is naturally a group by addition of coefficients , monomial - wise .",
    "but it becomes a ring by adding the intuitive multiplication law if and only if each element of @xmath1 can be represented only _ in a finite number of ways _ as a sum of two elements of @xmath1 , which is equivalent to the fact that @xmath1 is pointed .",
    "this explains why we needed to work only with exponents in @xmath174 in the previous definition .    in the particular case when @xmath1 is pointed",
    ", the sum   takes the simpler form : @xmath731 with @xmath732 . in this case , we write @xmath28 $ ] instead of @xmath729 $ ] and we call this ring _ the power series ring over _ @xmath1",
    ".    if @xmath46 , then the ring @xmath28 $ ] is isomorphic to the ring @xmath733 $ ] of formal power series in @xmath47 variables with coefficients in @xmath9 .",
    "the semigroup @xmath1 embeds naturally into the multiplicative semigroups of the rings @xmath541 $ ] and @xmath28 $ ] .",
    "moreover , a section @xmath734 of @xmath168 induces an embedding @xmath735 $ ] : @xmath736,\\ ] ] ( the monomial counterpart of the isomorphism @xmath737 from the end of the proof of lemma [ splitting ] ) .",
    "notice that , if @xmath738 is another section of @xmath168 , then @xmath739 and @xmath740 differ by a unit , i.e. , for any @xmath741 $ ] , there exists an element @xmath742 such that @xmath743 . in",
    "what follows , we consider also the localization @xmath744_{(\\gamma^+)}$ ] of the semigroup ring @xmath541 $ ] at its ideal @xmath745 .",

    "in this section we explain the notion of _ standard basis _ of an ideal @xmath44 in a formal power series ring @xmath28 $ ] with respect to a _",
    "local monomial ordering _ , which is a local analog of the notion of _ grbner basis _ of an ideal in a polynomial ring with respect to a monomial ordering .",
    "we prove the existence of a _ universal standard basis _ , that is , of a finite set of elements of @xmath44 which are a standard basis with respect to _ all _ local monomial orderings .    as stated in theorem [ t:3defs ] point [ invp ] ) , the global tropicalization of a subvariety of a torus can be obtained also by looking at the initial ideals of the defining ideal of the subvariety with respect to all weight vectors .",
    "such weight vectors define preorders on the lattice of monomials of the torus , compatible with the addition .",
    "usually they are studied by also bringing into the game total orderings compatible with the addition .",
    "those total orderings allow to define the notion of _ grbner basis _ ( see @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) .",
    "we refer to @xcite and @xcite for their application to the study of tropicalization of subvarieties of tori .    here",
    ", we develop an analogous theory of _ standard basis _ in formal power series rings @xmath28 $ ] , where @xmath1 is an affine pointed semigroup . in the next two sections we use it to study the local tropicalizations of ideals in",
    "@xmath28 $ ] .    a _ preorder _ on a set is a binary relation which is both reflexive and transitive",
    "partial order _ is a preorder which is antisymmetric .",
    "total preorder _ is a preorder such that any two elements of the set are comparable and a _ total order _ is a total preorder which is also a partial order .",
    "well ordered set _ is a set endowed with a total order such that any nonempty subset has a minimum .",
    "[ d : locord ] a * local monomial ordering * on an affine pointed semigroup @xmath1 is an order relation @xmath813 on the set @xmath1 such that + ( i ) @xmath53 is the least element ; + ( ii ) @xmath813 is a total ordering ; + ( iii ) @xmath813 is compatible with addition on @xmath1 , i.  e. , if @xmath814 , then @xmath815 for any @xmath816 .",
    "if @xmath817 and @xmath818 , we will also write @xmath819 . this explains the name _ monomial ordering _ : it is an order on the monomials of @xmath28 $ ] .    in the sequel , by a _",
    "monomial ordering _",
    "we shall always mean a local monomial ordering .",
    "the following proposition is standard for @xmath820 ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter 2.4 , cor .",
    "6 ) , where it is proved using the so - called _ dickson lemma _ on finite generation by monomials of monomial ideals ) .",
    "we give here a proof which does not pass through an analog of dickson s lemma .",
    "[ wellord ] under the axioms ( ii ) and ( iii ) , condition ( i ) is equivalent to the fact that @xmath813 is a well - ordering of @xmath1 .",
    "assume that @xmath813 is an ordering on @xmath1 which satisfies the axioms ( ii ) and ( iii ) .",
    "suppose first that @xmath813 is a well - ordering of @xmath1 .",
    "arguing by contradiction , if ( i ) is not true , then there exists @xmath821 such that @xmath822 . using axiom ( ii )",
    ", we get the following infinite chain of inequalities : @xmath823 .",
    "this implies that the set @xmath824 has no minimal element , which contradicts the hypothesis that we have a well - ordering .",
    "suppose then that axiom ( i ) is satisfied , in addition to ( ii ) and ( iii ) .",
    "choose a finite generating set @xmath825 of non - zero elements of @xmath1 , which exists by the hypothesis that @xmath1 is an affine semigroup .",
    "assume by contradiction that @xmath1 is not well - ordered .",
    "then we get an infinite decreasing sequence @xmath826 of elements of @xmath1 .",
    "choose also an expression @xmath827 for each element of the sequence in terms of the chosen generating set .",
    "that is , @xmath828 for all @xmath829 .",
    "such expressions are in general not unique , but this does not matter here . by axiom ( i ) , as the @xmath830 are non - vanishing , we see that @xmath831 .",
    "consider now an arbitrary @xmath832 .",
    "as @xmath833 , by axiom ( ii ) there exists an index @xmath834 such that @xmath835 . as the sequence @xmath836 is infinite , we may extract an infinite subsequence in which @xmath837 and @xmath838 are constant . repeating this argument a finite number of times , we arrive at an infinite strictly decreasing sequence in which all the coefficients @xmath839 are constant when @xmath840 varies , which is a contradiction .",

    "the presence of a monomial ordering allows to extend the theory of divisibility from monomials to arbitrary series :    [ l : division ] _",
    "( division algorithm ) _ let @xmath813 be a fixed monomial ordering on @xmath1 . if @xmath795 $ ] and @xmath853^p$ ] is an ordered collection of series , then there are series @xmath854 $ ] such that : @xmath855 where @xmath856 for all @xmath857 such that @xmath858 , @xmath859 , and none of the monomials of @xmath860 is divisible by any of the monomials @xmath861 .",
    "we simply apply the analog for series of the division algorithm for grbner basis ( see @xcite , @xcite , @xcite ) . here",
    "this algorithm involves an infinite number of steps , which compute the coefficients of the unknown series @xmath862 .",
    "first , we find the smallest term @xmath863 , @xmath864 , @xmath865 , of @xmath495 which is divisible by some @xmath866 , @xmath859 . if @xmath867 is the first such @xmath857 , we reduce @xmath495 by defining : @xmath868 where @xmath869 .",
    "we repeat the same process with @xmath870 instead of @xmath495 , defining @xmath871 , and continue in the same way .    in the limit",
    ", we get a reduction @xmath872 which has the property that no monomial of it is divisible by any @xmath866 , @xmath859 .",
    "this is the remainder .",
    "looking at the way we compute the sequence of reductions of @xmath495 , we see that @xmath873 is indeed of the form @xmath874 , with @xmath856 for all @xmath857 such that @xmath858 , @xmath875 .",
    "[ divrem ] this division result is usually presented for the ring of formal power series @xmath876 $ ] .",
    "an analogous ( but more complicated ) result for the ring of _ convergent _ power series @xmath877 was proved by grauert ( see @xcite ) , but we will not need it here .",
    "notice from the previous proof that the quotients @xmath878 , as well as the remainder @xmath860 , are uniquely determined by the process _ if we carefully respect the order of the collection _ @xmath879 .",
    "but , in general , even the remainder changes if we change this order , as we show in the next example .",
    "take the ring @xmath880 $ ] with the lexicographic ordering in which @xmath881 , and the series @xmath882 .",
    "then , @xmath883 , which shows that @xmath884 .",
    "if we permute @xmath885 and @xmath886 , we get @xmath887 .",
    "this non - uniqueness of the remainder is eliminated if we take a _",
    "standard basis _ instead of an arbitrary sequence ( see proposition [ p : basisquot ] ) .",
    "let @xmath813 be a monomial ordering on @xmath1 and @xmath44 an ideal of @xmath28 $ ] .",
    "a finite sequence @xmath888 for some @xmath889 or , by abuse of language , the underlying set is called a * standard basis * for @xmath44 with respect to the ordering @xmath813 if the initial monomials of the elements of @xmath890 generate the initial ideal @xmath842 .",
    "a finite set @xmath891 is called a * universal standard basis * for @xmath44 if @xmath892 is a standard basis for @xmath44 for any local monomial ordering @xmath813 on @xmath1 .",
    "[ remstand ] the terminology _ standard basis _ was introduced in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter iii.1 ) for a slightly different concept , not involving any ordering .",
    "the existence of a standard basis for any ideal @xmath893 $ ] and any monomial ordering @xmath813 on @xmath1 follows from noetherianness of @xmath28 $ ] by a standard argument of the theory of grbner bases .",
    "the following three propositions are also standard .    if @xmath890 is a standard basis for an ideal @xmath894 $ ] with respect to some monomial ordering , then @xmath890 generates @xmath44 .",
    "the next proposition shows that a standard basis induces a well - defined normal form for any element of @xmath28 / i$ ] .",
    "it corresponds to the remainder of the division by this basis .",
    "[ p : basisquot ] let @xmath813 be a monomial ordering on @xmath1 and @xmath44 be an ideal of @xmath28 $ ] .",
    "suppose that @xmath895 is an associated standard basis .",

    "every element of @xmath28 / i$ ] has a unique representative as a series whose monomials have exponents in the complement @xmath897 .",
    "this normal form is the remainder of the division algorithm by @xmath895 .    in particular , the remainder of the division of any element of @xmath44 by a standard basis of @xmath44 is necessarily @xmath53 .",
    "in fact , this characterizes standard basis :    [ charstand ] let @xmath813 be a monomial ordering on @xmath1 and @xmath44 be an ideal of @xmath28 $ ] .",
