    "a monomial order remains standard for conveniently defined _ neighboring _ orders .",
    "following sikora @xcite , boldini @xcite and @xcite , we see now that there is indeed a notion of topology on the space of monomial orders such that standard bases are locally constant .",
    "let @xmath450 be any set .",
    "denote by : @xmath942 the set of all total orderings of @xmath450 .",
    "one has a natural topology on it . intuitively , given two elements @xmath943 such that @xmath944 for some ordering @xmath945 , then this strict inequality should also hold in a neighborhood of @xmath813 .",
    "therefore , one is forced to declare the subsets : @xmath946 _ open _",
    ", for all @xmath947 .",
    "therefore , we endow @xmath948 with the topology generated by them .    in the case when @xmath450 is a semigroup and we only take the orderings that are compatible with the semigroup law , this topology was defined by sikora @xcite . the extension to arbitrary sets was done by boldini @xcite .",
    "sikora proved that under the additional hypothesis that @xmath450 is countable the associated topology is compact .",
    "boldini proved the analogous fact for an arbitrary countable set :    if the set @xmath450 is countable , then the space @xmath948 is compact .    given an element @xmath949 , let @xmath950 be the subspace of @xmath948 consisting of all total orderings for which the element @xmath87 is minimal , i.e. , @xmath951 @xmath952 .",
    "the subspace @xmath950 is closed in @xmath948 for each @xmath949 . hence , if @xmath450 is countable , @xmath950 is compact .",
    "now we let @xmath953 be an affine pointed semigroup .",
    "we denote by : @xmath954 the set of all monomial orderings on @xmath1 .",
    "@xmath955 is a closed compact subset of @xmath956 .",
    "let @xmath44 be an ideal of @xmath28 $ ] , and @xmath890 a finite subset of @xmath44 .",
    "then , the set of all monomial orderings @xmath813 such that @xmath890 is a standard basis with respect to @xmath813 is open in @xmath955 .",
    "the proof is essentially the same as in @xcite . in view of lemma",
    "[ l : twoorders ] , we must only replace the support of @xmath890 with the set of monomials of the series from @xmath890 lying on the union of newton diagrams of elements of @xmath890 .",
    "it is not obvious from the definition that universal standard basis indeed exist .",
    "nevertheless , it is an immediate consequence of the compactness of the space of monomial orderings :    any ideal of the ring @xmath28 $ ] has a universal standard basis .",
    "our argument is similar to that of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  2.14 ) . the family @xmath957 , where @xmath890 runs over all finite subsets of @xmath44 , forms an open covering of the space @xmath955 .",
    "since @xmath955 is compact , we can choose a finite subcovering @xmath958 .",
    "we conclude that the union @xmath959 is a universal standard basis of @xmath44 .",
    "the following proposition will be used in the proof of theorem  [ existrop ] :    [ p : ugb ] if @xmath960 is a universal standard basis for an ideal @xmath893 $ ] and @xmath961 , then @xmath962 is a universal standard basis for the initial ideal @xmath790 .",

    "* theorem 11 ) , in this section we prove the existence of tropical bases of ideals of @xmath28 $ ] .",
    "these bases are particular systems of generators of @xmath44 that allow us to compute @xmath48 as the intersection of local tropicalizations of hypersurfaces defined by these generators .",
    "[ d : tbasis ] let @xmath1 be a pointed affine semigroup .",
    "a * tropical basis * of an ideal @xmath44 of the ring @xmath28 $ ] is a universal standard basis @xmath996 of @xmath44 such that for any @xmath843 , the ideal @xmath790 contains a monomial if and only if one of the initial terms @xmath997 is a monomial .",
    "it is not always true that a universal standard basis is tropical :    we consider the same polynomials as the ones chosen in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* example 10 ) , but this time seen as generators of an ideal of the ring @xmath998 $ ] of formal power series in three variables .",
    "namely , we take : @xmath999 any two of the last three polynomials are redundant as generators , but they are needed in order to get a universal standard basis .",
    "we show that the four generators of @xmath44 form a universal standard basis of @xmath44 .",
    "consider an arbitrary monomial ordering @xmath813 .",
    "we have to show that the initial ideal @xmath1000 is generated by the initial terms of these four polynomials .",
    "since the set is symmetric in @xmath1001 , it is enough to study the case when @xmath1002 .",
    "therefore , we have to show that @xmath1000 is generated by the monomials @xmath226 and @xmath1003 ( @xmath1004 implies @xmath1005 ) .    which monomials are not in the ideal generated by @xmath226 and @xmath1003 ? only those of the form @xmath1006 , and @xmath1007 .",
    "let us show that none of these belongs to @xmath1000 .",
    "consider first the case of @xmath1007 .",
    "if @xmath1008 , then there exist two series @xmath1009 $ ] such that @xmath1007 is the @xmath813-initial term of : @xmath1010 since @xmath1011 and @xmath1012 generate @xmath44 .",
    "first , let us substitute @xmath1013 ( take the quotient @xmath1014/(x)$ ] and consider the induced monomial order on it ) .",
    "we get : @xmath1015 @xmath1016 it follows that the initial term of @xmath1017 is @xmath1018 , and hence @xmath1018 has a non - zero coefficient in @xmath495 too .",
    "therefore , when we distribute the product @xmath1019 , we get the monomial @xmath1020 as a term in this expansion . but @xmath1021 .",
    "therefore , it must cancel in . as this monomial does not appear in @xmath1022",
    ", we see that @xmath1020 cancels only if @xmath495 contains also the monomial @xmath1023 . again",
    ", then the product @xmath1019 contains @xmath1023 which is less than @xmath1020 and @xmath1007 .",
    "we conclude that @xmath495 contains also @xmath1024 , and so on .",
    "but then we come to a contradiction , because the series @xmath495 does not have any negative powers of @xmath711 .",
    "the argument for @xmath1025 and @xmath1018 is similar and even easier , because we do not need to pass to the quotient @xmath1014/(x)$ ] .",
    "the fact that the four polynomials are not a tropical basis is proved now exactly as in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* example 10 ) .",
    "namely , consider the weight @xmath1026 .",
    "the four polynomials are equal to their initial terms with respect to @xmath20 ( they are homogeneous ) , therefore these initial terms are not monomials . but @xmath1027 , therefore @xmath790 contains the monomial @xmath1028 .",
    "this shows that the four polynomials do not form a tropical basis of @xmath44 .",
    "therefore , we are led to ask whether tropical bases for ideals of rings of the form @xmath28 $ ] exist necessarily .",
    "this is indeed the case :    [ existrop ] any ideal of the ring @xmath28 $ ] has a tropical basis .",
    "starting from any universal standard basis @xmath1029 of a given ideal @xmath44 , we shall construct a tropical basis of @xmath44 by adding new series to @xmath892 .",
    "note that the cone @xmath1030 is naturally stratified by the relative interiors of its faces : @xmath1031 furthermore , if @xmath791 $ ] , each @xmath783 can be considered as a function on the extended newton diagram @xmath794 of @xmath495 .",
    "this function takes its minimal value on some face of @xmath794 .",
    "we say that this face is _ cut by the function _",
    "now , we define an equivalence relation on the set of vectors of the cone @xmath217 : @xmath1032 if and only if @xmath20 and @xmath651 are contained in the same stratum @xmath412 and for all @xmath857 , @xmath1033 , @xmath20 and @xmath651 cut the same face of @xmath1034 .",
    "the reader can easily check that there are only finite number of equivalence classes of @xmath129 , that they give a new stratification of @xmath217 refining the one described above , and the closure of each equivalence class is a rational polyhedral cone .",
    "the set of these cones is a fan that we denote by @xmath1035 .",

    "it may be immediately extended in our context .",
    "let @xmath414 be a cone of @xmath1035 such that for some ( and thus for any ) @xmath1037 the initial ideal @xmath790 contains a monomial .",

    "finally , we generalize the notion of tropical basis so that it allows also to study the initial ideals corresponding to arbitrary , not necessarily finite , vectors @xmath1052 .",
    "if @xmath231 is a face of @xmath230 , we consider the _ @xmath231-truncation _ @xmath1053 of the ideal @xmath44 ( see definition  [ trunc ] ) .",
    "it is easy to see that any element of @xmath1053 is a truncation of some element of @xmath44 . for each @xmath231 , let us choose a finite set @xmath1054 of elements of @xmath44 such that the set of truncations of @xmath1054 is a tropical basis for @xmath1053 .",
    "setting : @xmath1055 we get a finite subset of @xmath44 such that its truncation in every @xmath1056 $ ] is a tropical basis of @xmath1053 .",
    "we turn this property into a definition :    [ extropbas ] a finite subset of an ideal @xmath44 of @xmath28 $ ] , such that its truncation in every ring @xmath1056 $ ] for varying faces @xmath231 of @xmath230 is a tropical basis of @xmath1053 is called an * extended tropical basis * of @xmath44 .    an extended tropical basis @xmath890 may be characterized also by the property that for any face @xmath231 of @xmath217 and any @xmath1057 , the initial ideal @xmath790 ( considered as an ideal of the ring @xmath1056 $ ] ) contains a monomial if and only if one of the initial forms @xmath789 , @xmath1058 , is a monomial .",
    "our main goal here is to describe the piecewise - linear structure of the local tropicalization .",
    "we were not able to prove this fact in full generality .",

    "then , by theorem  [ existrop ] and theorem  [ tropinit ] ( ii ) , in a neighborhood of @xmath20 the positive tropicalization of an ideal @xmath44 coincides with that of the initial ideal @xmath790 .    in the sequel we want to make a clear distinction between a _ fan _ and a set which is the _ support of a fan _ , but without fixed fan structure .",
    "that is why we introduce the following definition :    [ d : conicalset ] a * pl cone * in a vector space @xmath339 is a subset @xmath1083 that can be represented as a finite union of convex polyhedral cones .",
    "it is called * rational * , if it can be represented as a finite union of rational convex polyhedral cones , that is , if it is the support of a fan .",
    "a subset @xmath1084 of a linear variety @xmath361 is called a * ( rational ) pl conical subspace * if for each stratum @xmath1085 the intersection @xmath1086 is empty or a ( rational ) pl cone .",
    "the following are examples of pl cones and pl conical subspaces :    the * newton cone * of a series @xmath791 $ ] , denoted @xmath1087 , is the set of vectors @xmath783 such that , seen as a function on the newton diagram @xmath793 , @xmath20 attains its minimum on a face of positive dimension .",
    "if @xmath1088 , we set @xmath1089 by definition .",
    "the * extended newton cone * of @xmath495 is the disjoint union @xmath1090 , where @xmath1080 is the @xmath231-truncation of @xmath495 .    if @xmath785 and @xmath1091 , where @xmath821 and @xmath1092 is a unit in @xmath28 $ ] , then the newton cone is indeed a rational pl conical subspace of pure dimension @xmath1093 , where @xmath47 is the rank of the lattice @xmath1094 .",
    "notice that our newton cone is different from what is usually called the _ normal fan _ of @xmath495 .",
    "the newton cone is the support of the @xmath1095-skeleton of the standard normal fan .",

    "@xmath0 the coordinate ring of a subvariety of the torus @xmath1159 $ ] , and @xmath1160 the natural morphism .",
    "the field @xmath9 is supposed to be endowed with an arbitrary ( not necessarily trivial ) real valuation .",
    "this leads to a global tropicalization that is a pl ( but not necessarily conical ) subspace .",

    "if @xmath1062 and @xmath1215 is a representative of @xmath622 in @xmath1181[[\\gamma]]$ ] , let @xmath1216 be its leading term ( with respect to @xmath813 ) with @xmath1217 .",
    "then , we can find an element @xmath1218 with leading term @xmath1219 , @xmath1220 .",
    "take the reduction @xmath1221 . in this way",
    ", we delete from @xmath622 all monomials contained in the initial ideal @xmath1222 .",
    "moreover , under such a reduction the terms of @xmath622 that are less than @xmath719 remain unchanged . thus , despite the reduction process is infinite , the terms that are less than a given monomial @xmath719 can change only a finite number of times .",
    "this shows that the result of the reduction is an element of @xmath1181[[\\gamma]]$ ] .",
    "we see , in particular , that @xmath450 has no torsion as a @xmath1181$]-module . over a principal ideal domain",
    "this is equivalent to being flat ( ( * ? ? ?",

    "* corollary  6.3 ) ) .",
    "[ l : prime ] if @xmath893 $ ] is a prime ideal , then @xmath1223[[\\gamma]]$ ] is also prime .",

    ", we come to a situation when either one of the series in the product is @xmath53 , and thus @xmath87 or @xmath1237 , or every coefficient of every term of @xmath87 or @xmath126 takes value @xmath53 under the substitution @xmath1227 . in this case",
    "every coefficient of @xmath87 ( or @xmath126 ) is divisible by @xmath1238 .",
    "then we have a relation of the form : @xmath1239 where @xmath1240 and @xmath1241 .",
    "but since the algebra @xmath1184[[\\gamma]]/i_t$ ] has a basis consisting of monomials , it follows that @xmath1242 .",
    "notice that after a finite number of the previous two steps the initial monomial @xmath719 of @xmath87 or @xmath126 will drop with respect to the chosen monomial ordering .",
    "after this , new reductions involve only the monomials strictly greater than @xmath719 .",
    "this implies the convergence of the process of reduction of @xmath87 and @xmath126 .",
    "thus , @xmath1243 or @xmath1237 , as we wanted to show .",
    "[ l : equidim ] the ring @xmath1181[[\\gamma]]/i_t$ ] is equidimensional , that is , if @xmath1244 and @xmath1245 are any two maximal ideals in this ring , then the height of @xmath1244 equals the height of @xmath1245 .",

    "thus , we have the equality @xmath1276 .",
    "the proof for the nonnegative tropicalization is similar .",

    "in fact , we can reconstruct the global tropicalization of a subvariety or a subscheme @xmath23 over a field @xmath9 of a toric variety @xmath1366 from the local tropicalizations of the germs of this subscheme at the orbits of some birational modification of @xmath1366 . if @xmath23 does not pass through any such orbit ( e.g. , @xmath1372 ) , then the global tropicalization of @xmath23 consists of one point and there is essentially nothing to reconstruct .",
    "so , let us suppose that this is not the case .",

    "we shall only outline the main ideas in the proof , leaving the details to the reader .",
    "it suffices to show that for each point @xmath150 of @xmath548 , the closure of @xmath23 in the toric variety @xmath1366 contains the orbit @xmath1436 .",
    "the ideal @xmath1437 of the closure of @xmath23 in the affine toric variety @xmath1438 is generated by all polynomials @xmath1439 whose support is contained in @xmath1440 .",
    "a sufficient condition for such a polynomial @xmath1441 to vanish on @xmath1436 is that the extended newton diagram @xmath794 is not generated by one point , i.e. , there is no @xmath768 such that @xmath1442 . but",
    "this condition indeed holds for each @xmath1443 because @xmath1444 and @xmath548 and @xmath247 are transversal .",
    "in this section , we show that tropicalization is an invariant of the ambient toroidal structure .",
    "more precisely , the tropicalization of an algebraic , analytic or formal germ of subvariety of an affine toric variety at its closed orbit , depends only on the associated toroidal structure .",
    "we use this fact to define the tropicalization of a subvariety of a toroidal embedding .",
    "the basic reference for the notions used in this section is ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter ii ) .",
    "first , we recall the basic definitions and fix the notations .",
    "the ground field @xmath9 will be assumed to be algebraically closed .",
    "( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter ii , definition 1 ) ) .",
    "a * toroidal embedding * over a field @xmath9 is a pair @xmath1445 , where @xmath1446 is a zariski open subset of a normal algebraic variety @xmath23 over @xmath9 , such that for every closed point @xmath1447 there exists an affine toric variety @xmath1448 over @xmath9 , where @xmath1415 is the open torus @xmath1449 , a closed point @xmath1450 , and an isomorphism of @xmath9-local algebras : @xmath1451 such that the ideal in @xmath1452 generated by the ideal of @xmath1453 maps isomorphically to the ideal in @xmath1454 generated by the ideal of @xmath1455 .",
    "notice that the previous definition implies that @xmath311 is smooth .",
    "the notation @xmath1445 , with @xmath311 coming first , is intended to suggest that @xmath23 is thought of as a total space into which @xmath311 embedds and that , as for toric varieties , this total space may change without changing @xmath311 .    the orbit of @xmath1450 can always be assumed closed , by diminishing perhaps @xmath1456 .",
    "such a pair @xmath1457 , together with a formal isomorphism as above is called a _ local model _ of @xmath1458 at @xmath226 .",
    "the definition implies that the irreducible components of @xmath1453 ( if nonempty ) have codimension @xmath18 in @xmath23 .",
    "we denote them by @xmath1459 , so that @xmath1460 .",
    "if all the varieties @xmath1461 are normal , a toroidal embedding @xmath1445 is called a _ toroidal embedding without self intersections_.    the set @xmath311 and the connected components of the sets @xmath1462 , @xmath1463 , define a natural _ stratification _ of the space @xmath23 .",
    "if @xmath1464 is a stratum , the _ star _ @xmath1465 of @xmath1464 is the union of all strata @xmath1466 such that @xmath1464 is contained in the closure of @xmath1466 .",
    "let @xmath1464 be a stratum .",
    "following ( * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter ii , definition 3 ) , we denote :    * @xmath1467 the group of cartier divisors on @xmath1465 , + supported on the hypersurface @xmath1468 ; * @xmath1469 ; * @xmath1470 subsemigroup of @xmath1471 of effective divisors ; * @xmath1472 .",
    "note that the cone @xmath1473 is strongly convex and that @xmath1474 .",
    "let @xmath1464 be a stratum of the toroidal embedding without self - intersection @xmath1458 .",
    "then , the completion @xmath1475 of the local ring of @xmath23 at @xmath1464 is isomorphic to the ring @xmath1476 $ ] of formal power series over the semigroup @xmath1477 with coefficients in the field @xmath1478 of rational functions on @xmath1464 .",
    "this isomorphism is defined up to multiplication by units .    each cartier divisor on @xmath1465 defines a principal ideal in the local ring @xmath1479 .",
    "thus , to each element of @xmath1477 we may assign a defining function , i.e. , an element of @xmath1479 ( well - defined up to a unit ) .",
    "we define this correspondence on a set of elements of @xmath1477 which form a basis of @xmath1480 and then extend it to all of @xmath1477 .",
    "we obtain a morphism of semigroups @xmath1481 .",
    "notice also that the ring @xmath1479 and hence its completion @xmath1475 , contain a field , say , the field @xmath9 .",
    "then , it follows from the theory of complete rings ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* chapter v ) ) that @xmath1475 contains also a field isomorphic to its residue field , that is to @xmath1478 .",
    "let us fix such a subfield .",
    "in this way , we get a morphism of rings : @xmath1482\\to \\widehat{\\mathcal{o}}_{x , y},\\ ] ] unique up to a unit .",
    "we now prove that it is an isomorphism of complete local rings .",
    "the injectivity of @xmath1483 is clear , so let us prove the surjectivity .",
    "since @xmath1479 naturally embeds into its completion @xmath1475 and the ring @xmath1476 $ ] is complete , it suffices to prove that @xmath1479 lies in the image of @xmath1476 $ ] .",
    "first , note that the image of @xmath1477 generates the maximal ideal of @xmath1479 .",
    "indeed , consider the diagram : @xmath1484 of rings , where @xmath226 is a closed point of the stratum @xmath1464 and @xmath1457 is a local model at @xmath226 . by the properties of toroidal embeddings ( see ( * ? ? ?",

    "this last ideal is generated by the image of @xmath1477 in @xmath1454 .",

    "this proves that @xmath1483 is surjective , as we wanted to show .",

    "conical polyhedral complex with integral structure_. let us recall the construction .",

    "* chapter ii , definition 5 ) ) .",
    "a * conical polyhedral complex * @xmath247 is formed by :    * a topological space @xmath1497 ; * a finite family of closed subsets @xmath1498 called * cones * ; * a finite dimensional real vector space @xmath1499 of real valued continuous functions on @xmath1498 such that :    1 .   a basis of",

    "faces of @xmath1501 correspond also to cones of @xmath247 ; 3 .",
    "@xmath1497 is a disjoint union of relative interiors of @xmath1498 for all @xmath857 ; 4 .",
    "if @xmath1502 is a face of @xmath1498 , then the restriction of @xmath1499 to @xmath1502 is @xmath1503 .    even if we use the same notation as for fans of cones , it is important to note that in a conical polyhedral complex we do not have an embedding of the various cones in a fixed vector space . in particular , if we consider the conical polyhedral complex associated to a fan , we loose the information about this embedding .",

    "let @xmath1445 be a toroidal embedding .",

    "@xmath1473 of the conical complex @xmath247 we have a linear variety @xmath1514 and the closure @xmath1515 ( see section  [ troptor ] ) . _",
    "the gluing of cones of @xmath247 naturally extends to a gluing of their closures_. more precisely , let @xmath1516 , @xmath1517 , and @xmath1466 be strata of @xmath1445 , and suppose that @xmath1516 and @xmath1517 are contained in the closure of @xmath1466 .",
    "recall that @xmath1518 is defined as the set of all nonnegative simigroup homomorphisms from @xmath1519 to @xmath308 , and similarly @xmath1520 and @xmath1521 . since @xmath1522 is naturally a sublattice of both @xmath1523 and @xmath1524 , and @xmath1511",
    "is a common face of @xmath1525 and @xmath1526 , @xmath1527 is a common subset of @xmath1528 and @xmath1529 .",
    "this allows to glue the extended cones @xmath1518 and @xmath1520 along @xmath1521 .",
    "the stratum at infinity of @xmath1518 that corresponds to the face @xmath1511 is equipped with the lattice @xmath1530 and the vector space @xmath1531 . for an illustration in dimension two , see example  [ ex : toroitrop ] and the accompanying figure  [ fig : toroitrop ] .",
    "let @xmath247 be the conical complex of a toroidal embedding @xmath1445 .",
    "denote by @xmath1532 the topological space obtained by gluing the extended cones of @xmath247 as explained before .",
    "equip it with the additional structure @xmath1471 that is inherited from @xmath247 , and with all the analogous additional structure ( quotient lattices , vector spaces of real functions ) on the strata of @xmath1515 at infinity .",
    "we call it the * extended conical complex * of the toroidal embedding @xmath1445 , denoted @xmath403",
    ".    now , let @xmath1533 be an ideal sheaf on a toroidal embedding @xmath1445 defining a subscheme @xmath710 .",

    ", these tropicalizations do not depend on the choice of an isomorphism between @xmath1475 and @xmath1476 $ ] .",
    "let @xmath1464 and @xmath1466 be strata , and @xmath1541 . if @xmath1542 , then : @xmath1543    the proof is essentially the same as the proof of lemma  [ l : compatibilityofltrop ] .",
    "this lemma justifies the following definition :    let @xmath710 be a subscheme of a toroidal embedding @xmath1445 .",
    "the disjoint union : @xmath1544 of positive tropicalizations of all germs of @xmath710 at strata of @xmath1445 , considered as a subset of the extended conical complex @xmath403 of the toroidal embedding @xmath1445 is called the * tropicalization * of the subscheme @xmath710 .",
    "let @xmath710 be a subscheme of a toroidal embedding @xmath1445 .",
    "then for every stratum @xmath1464 of @xmath1445 the intersection @xmath1545 is a rational polyhedral conical set . if the germ of @xmath710 at @xmath1464 has pure dimension @xmath52 , then @xmath1545 has pure real dimension @xmath52 .",
    "the proof follows from theorem  [ t : main ] .",
    "[ ex : toroitrop ] in the top part of figure [ fig : toroitrop ] is represented a ( singular ) curve @xmath710 in a smooth surface @xmath23 , and @xmath1546 are smooth curves of @xmath23 crossing normally in succession at the points @xmath1547 . therefore , if @xmath1548 , the pair @xmath1549 is a toroidal embedding . in the bottom part of the figure we represent the associated tropicalisation , which is obtained by gluing the positive local tropicalisations in the neighborhood of the points @xmath1547 .",
    "we denote by @xmath1550 the 2-dimensional cone corresponding to each point @xmath1551 , and by @xmath1552 the @xmath18-dimensional cone corresponding to the curve @xmath1461 , for each @xmath1553 .",
    "notice that at the point @xmath1554 we have two irreducible components of @xmath710 , but that their tropicalizations coincide , as both are smooth and transversal to @xmath1555 and @xmath1556 .    at 140 457 at 240 363 at 364 469 at 144 146 at 260 196 at 394 150 at 95 223 at 200 260 at 414 236 at 170 483 at 88 480 at 200 320 at 495 370 at 236 436 at 136 56 at 180 84 at 266 100 at 320 56",
    "there is yet a more general version of local tropicalization .",
    "we are not going to develop the theory here , but , as we promised in introduction , we shall describe the main idea of the construction .    if @xmath0 is any commutative ring with unit and @xmath1557 its group of units , then , as explained after definition [ congr ] , we can define the quotient @xmath1558 as a multiplicative semigroup .",
    "any nonnegative valuation @xmath150 on @xmath0 defines a semigroup morphism @xmath1559 ( the argument is the same as the one given in the proof of proposition  [ p : toroidalinvariance ] ) .",
    "then , we can speak about tropicalization of subsets @xmath1560 not only in the presence of semigroup morphisms @xmath550 , but also of morphisms defined modulo units , that is of semigroup morphisms : @xmath1561    this yields a functorial construction that generalizes the one described in section [ s : defoftrop ] .",
    "for instance , let @xmath1312 be a point ( not necessarily closed ) of a normal algebraic variety ( over an arbitrary algebraically closed field @xmath9 ) or an analytic space @xmath23 . from now on , we consider @xmath23 as a germ at the point @xmath1312",
    "let @xmath1562 be a reduced hypersurface on @xmath23 .",
    "_ we do not assume that the pair @xmath67 is toroidal in any sense_. let @xmath1 be the semigroup of effective cartier divisors supported on @xmath63 .",
    "the semigroup @xmath1 generalizes of the semigroup @xmath1563 defined in section  [ toroidal ] .",
    "since the semigroup of _ all _ effective cartier divisors on @xmath23 is isomorphic to @xmath1564 , the semigroup @xmath1 is naturally embedded in @xmath1564 .",
    "this embedding is given by assigning to each cartier divisor a defining function ( well - defined modulo a unit ) .",
    "let us show that @xmath1 is an affine semigroup .",
    "denote by @xmath208 the group of all weil divisors supported on @xmath63 , and by @xmath272 the group of all cartier divisors supported on @xmath63 .",
    "the group @xmath208 is free , thus @xmath272 is free as a subgroup of @xmath208 .",
    "all effective weil @xmath918-divisors form a rational polyhedral cone @xmath217 of maximal dimension in @xmath1565 .",
    "thus @xmath1566 is finitely generated by gordan s lemma ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* section 1.2 , proposition 1 ) ) .",
    "we conclude that @xmath1 is indeed an affine semigroup . therefore , whenever a hypersurface @xmath63 on a normal germ @xmath23 is fixed , we can tropicalize any ideal @xmath44 of the local ring @xmath1567 , by considering either the positive or the nonnegative local tropicalization of the canonical map @xmath1568 , where @xmath1569 .    in this way",
    ", we extend the notions of positive and nonnegative local tropicalizations to the case of local semigroup morphisms @xmath1570 , where @xmath0 is an arbitrary local ring .",
    "in this section we compare our work with other results in the literature , we sketch some possible directions of development and we conclude by stating two open problems",
    ".    there are already several books and plenty of papers on tropical geometry .",
    "the field is developing very fast , and sometimes ideas come to minds of several authors almost simultaneously .",
    "it may well happen that our work is very close to something already done or something currently being developed by other researchers . in this section",
    "we would like to explain what we think is new in our approach and what is taken from other sources .",
    "the idea of tropicalization , though the term itself is relatively new , appeared already in bergman s paper @xcite from 1971 .",
    "even all three definitions of the tropicalization ( using valuations , the definition based on initial ideals , and the one using @xmath9-valued points ) are present there .",
    "bieri and groves @xcite proposed the elegant point of view that the piecewise - linear complexes that are now called tropicalizations are _ invariants of the morphisms @xmath1571 from a finitely generated free abelian group @xmath254 to the multiplicative group @xmath1572 of a field @xmath9 _ or , more generally , of the morphisms @xmath1573 to the multiplicative semigroup of a ring @xmath0 .",
    "as the reader should remember , we defined local tropicalization as a subset of an extended affine space , and this subset corresponds to a morphism @xmath1574 from a semigroup @xmath1 .",
    "this generalizes bieri and groves point of view , though payne s work @xcite , where tropicalizations of embeddings into arbitrary toric varieties are studied , was also very motivating for us",
    ". extensions of affine spaces ( called linear varieties in our paper ) were already defined in @xcite . they are explained also in @xcite , @xcite and @xcite ; our presentation has no substantial differences , but we describe in more detail the topology of those spaces .",
    "as far as we know , tropicalizations of semigroup morphisms @xmath1575 for arbitrary local rings @xmath0 have not been studied in the literature before .",
    "however , tropicalizations of not only algebraic but also analytic objects were defined and studied by touda @xcite , rabinoff @xcite , and gubler @xcite .    in fact , the main part of our paper ( sections  [ s : powerseriesring ] , [ s : lstruct ] , and [ s : localglobal ] ) were an extension of touda s work @xcite , though we started this project without knowing about it .",
    "touda studies tropicalizations of ideals in the ring of formal power series over the field @xmath703 of complex numbers .",
    "he works with the definition of local tropicalization using weights ( analog of the second one used for global tropicalization , as recalled in the introduction ) .",
    "he proves then a theorem about piecewise - linear structure of the local tropicalization . as an important tool in his proofs ,",
    "he uses the notion of local grbner fan of an ideal in a formal power series ring , as well as its properties proven by bahloul and takayama in @xcite .",
    "the differences with our approach are the following .",
    "we work in the more general setting of morphisms @xmath1574 , in particular , @xmath0 can be an algebra over an arbitrary field @xmath9 , and we consider general ring valuations which lead to local tropicalizations living in an extended affine space , whereas touda restricts only to the real part of the local tropicalization .",
    "another new result in our local finiteness theorem is the statement about dimension of local tropicalization .",
    "we should also note that some important steps of the construction of a tropical basis ( e.g. , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition  6.3 ) ) are left without proof in @xcite .",
    "the main objects of the papers @xcite and @xcite are rings of series with some convergence conditions over fields endowed with a _ nontrivial _ valuation and ideals in these rings . notice that our local conditions ( see definition  [ d : loctrop ] ) imply that if the local ring @xmath0 has a subfield @xmath9 , then any local valuation on @xmath0 is _ trivial _ on @xmath9 .",
    "thus we think that our work is in a way complementary to @xcite and @xcite .",
    "another important difference is that we could work completely without the theory of affinoid algebras that plays a major role in @xcite and @xcite , and in the proof of piecewise - linear structure of the tropicalization in @xcite .",
    "the local conditions lead also naturally to the question about extensions of nonnegative valuations treated in section  [ s : extval ] . despite the fact that the literature on the valuation theory is very rich",
    ", we are not aware of any reference for questions of this kind .    in the proof of the local finiteness theorem",
    "we follow well - known ideas .",
    "the use of grbner basis techniques in describing the structure of tropicalization is common , perhaps , since the paper @xcite of speyer and sturmfels . to show the existence of universal standard , or grbner , bases in power series rings we apply the method of sikora @xcite ( as explained by boldini in @xcite ) .",
    "different and more constructive proofs should exist , but we do not know about them",
    ". it would be interesting to check if sikora s method is applicable also to affinoid algebras . as it is said in (",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* remark  8.8 ) , a theorem on the existence of a universal standard basis for an ideal in an affinoid algebra would be an important part of the analytic tropical geometry .",
    "the method of a flat degeneration of an ideal to its initial ideal is rather standard , see , e.g. , ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  15.17 ) .",
    "the fact that an ideal @xmath44 and its initial ideal @xmath790 locally around @xmath20 have the same tropicalization has also been observed earlier , see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* remark  7.9.2 ) .",
    "as we showed in section  [ s : localglobal ] , the usual tropicalization of subvarieties of a torus or of a toric variety can be glued from the local tropicalizations . however , to claim that our local tropicalization generalizes the usual one would not be completely honest , since we essentially use properties of the tropicalization of subvarieties of toric varieties in the proof of theorem  [ t : main ] .",
    "we are not aware of any other treatment of tropicalization of subvarieties of toroidal embeddings .",
    "a new feature in this case is the absence of the `` big torus '' in a toroidal embedding .",
    "however , our local tropicalization is well suited for this situation since it uses only the `` formal torus embedding '' @xmath1576 $ ] .",
    "once the theory of tropicalization of ideals of the rings @xmath28 $ ] has been developed , the construction of tropicalization of subvarieties of toroidal embeddings is very natural and straightforward .",
    "one should be able to prove in the toroidal setting an analog of payne s main theorem from @xcite relating tropicalizations and analytifications in the berkovich sense .",
    "this would allow to make a bridge with thuillier s work @xcite on the analytification of toroidal embeddings .    our final general definition of tropicalization associated to a morphism of semigroups",
    "@xmath1577 should be useful as a starting point for tropicalizing log - structures .",
    "this seems to be one of the current directions of development of tropical geometry , as indicated by gross in his book @xcite and in his talk @xcite .",
    "indeed , a log - scheme is a scheme @xmath23 equipped with a morphism of sheaves of ( multiplicative ) semigroups @xmath1578 , such that @xmath1579 realizes an isomorphism between @xmath1580 and @xmath1581 .",
    "let @xmath1582 .",
    "quoting from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* ; * ? ? ?",
    "* page 101 ) : `` _ _ the sheaf of monoids @xmath1583 , written additively [ ... ] should be viewed as containing combinatorial information about the log structure _ _ '' . note that @xmath1579 induces a canonical morphism of sheaves of semigroups : @xmath1584 that is , we are ready for gluing our affine definitions of tropicalizations !    the fact that we have isolated the category of semigroups as part of the structure allowing tropicalization should allow us to also make connections with algebraic geometry over the field with one element , as described for instance by connes and consani in @xcite .",
    "as explained in chapter 3 of that paper , the category of semigroups and morphisms of semigroups is an essential component of it .",
    "another field which has already very important connections with tropical geometry is the theory of berkovich analytic spaces .",
    "as explained by berkovich @xcite , the category of semigroups also plays an important role there . as the title of berkovich s talk indicates ,",
    "this should be seen as part of a project of relating analytic geometry to geometry over the field with one element .",
    "let @xmath1585 be an arbitrary local morphism , where @xmath1 is a pointed affine semigroup and @xmath0 is a complete local ring .",
    "we do not suppose that @xmath5 is the natural morphism of @xmath1 to a quotient of a power series ring @xmath28 $ ] over a field @xmath9 , as in section [ s : lstruct ] .",
    "does the local tropicalization @xmath553 have piecewise - linear structure in such a general case ?",
    "this question is interesting both in the case when @xmath0 contains a field or when it does not .",
    "berkovich , v. g. , _ analytic geometry over @xmath1586_. talk given on the 4th of february 2011 at the conference `` from p - adic differential equations to arithmetic algebraic geometry '' , padova .",
    "http://www.wisdom.weizmann.ac.il/@xmath129vova/padova-slides@xmath15872011.pdf                                      gubler , w. , _ a guide to tropicalizations _ , in _ tropical geometry _",
    ", proceedings castro urdiales 2011 , e. brugall , m.a .",
    "cueto , a. dickenstein , e.m .",
    "feichtner and i. itenberg editors , contemp .",
    "mathematics , a. m. s. , 2013 , this volume ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> in this paper we propose a general functorial definition of the operation of _ local tropicalization _ in commutative algebra . </S>",
    "<S> let @xmath0 be a commutative ring , @xmath1 a finitely generated subsemigroup of a lattice , @xmath2 a morphism of semigroups , and @xmath3 the topological space of valuations on @xmath0 taking values in @xmath4 . </S>",
    "<S> then we may _ tropicalize _ with respect to @xmath5 any subset @xmath6 of the space of valuations @xmath3 . by definition </S>",
    "<S> , we get a subset of a rational polyhedral cone canonically associated to @xmath1 , enriched with strata at infinity . in particular , when @xmath0 is a local ring , @xmath5 is a _ local _ morphism of semigroups , and @xmath6 is the space of valuations which are either positive or non - negative on @xmath0 , we call these processes _ local tropicalizations_. they depend only on the ambient toroidal structure , which in turn allows to define tropicalizations of subvarieties of toroidal embeddings . we prove that with suitable hypothesis , these local tropicalizations are the supports of finite rational polyhedral fans enriched with strata at infinity and we compare the global and local tropicalizations of a subvariety of a toric variety . </S>"
  ]
}
